The passage also mentions that the Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee had planned to vote on authorizing 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, but postponed the vote at the request of the prime minister's office to avoid further straining relations with Washington ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry is expected to address the conflict and respond to "misleading critiques" of the Obama administration by the Israeli government. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas has stated that the resolution paves the way for the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France on 15 January, hoping it will lead to a mechanism and timetable to end the occupation.

The passage describes the Queen's 90th birthday celebrations, which include a series of events and tributes. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, visited the Royal Mail delivery office in Windsor, where she met staff and viewed an exhibition. She also attended a ceremony to open a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens and met pupils from six schools involved in its decoration. The Queen's birthday is marked by the release of ten stamps, including a sheet featuring four generations of the Royal Family. On her actual birthday, she and Prince Philip will unveil a plaque for The Queen's Walkway and light a beacon to mark the occasion. The passage also includes a BBC interview with Prince William, who praised the Queen as a "guiding example" and discussed his approach to royal duty.

In a match between Cheltenham Town (League Two) and West Ham United (Premier League) in the EFL Cup, West Ham United secured a 2-0 victory. The game saw two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew for West Ham before half-time, giving the Premier League side control. Cheltenham, who were unchanged from their previous league defeat, had several chances but could not capitalize, with the best moment being Harry Pell's low volley that was just off target. West Ham's Slaven Bilic's side could have won by a greater margin, but Cheltenham's Kyle Storer and West Ham's Jonathan Flatt made crucial saves. This result ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup before the third-round draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not want Werner to be sent to jail.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist from Southall, west London, attempted to return to the UK last year after fighting in Syria. He was a prominent British fighter in Syria, posting videos and pictures of his activities while masked. Khawaja was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State that used slick propaganda to recruit British Muslims. He was involved in fundraising, video diaries, and "through the keyhole" tours of fighters' quarters. Despite the group's glamorous portrayal of jihad, their content included gruesome scenes of death. Khawaja faked his own death with an online obituary and tried to return to Britain unnoticed, but was caught by the police at Dover. He is now facing a possible life sentence for his role in Syria's battlefields.

Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season for Wrexham, who finished eighth in the table. He is Barnsley's third signing for next season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson's pace and ability to get past defenders, stating he will fit in well with Barnsley's style of play. Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham to join Barnsley.

The passage describes a situation where bottles, believed to be from a container lost overboard from the MV Blue Ocean, have washed up on the Cornish coast, particularly at Poldhu Cove on the Lizard. National Trust volunteers have been clearing the bottles away due to concerns they pose a risk to wildlife. The bottles are sealed, but some have leaked, raising concerns about the impact on sensitive marine life. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency stated that while the MV Blue Ocean did lose a container containing 'Vanish' bottles, there is no concrete evidence linking the washed-up bottles to this incident. The loss of the container is believed to have occurred near Land's End in May. The Cornwall Wildlife Trust expressed high concern over the potential impact on marine life, and the National Trust has arranged for the bottles to be cleared. The public is advised to keep a safe distance from the bottles and not to attempt to recover them.

The incident took place on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00. Several people sustained minor injuries in the crash. The road was closed, and diversions were set up via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich route. Police Scotland are still investigating the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, played 14 games last season, helping Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite for his excellent contribution towards the end of the campaign. Following the team's promotion to the Championship, Dervite, along with David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, signed new contracts with Bolton.

The passage discusses the tensions between the Liberal Democrats and the Labour Party in the UK Parliament, particularly in the context of Brexit. Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being prepared to "concede everything," while Labour's leader in the Lords, Baroness Smith, responded that the Lib Dems were giving people "false hope." The two parties had previously teamed up to help defeat the government on issues related to EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, their cooperation ended when MPs rejected those amendments, with the Lib Dems determined to insist on them and Labour prepared to defer to the Commons. A Labour source in the Lords described the Lib Dems' actions as "fairly obvious grandstanding" aimed at their campaign leaflets. The Lib Dems' Europe spokesperson, Baroness Ludford, accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and "lining up with the Conservatives." Despite their differences, both parties have a history of forming alliances to impose government defeats on bills dealing with issues such as higher education and housing. Baroness Ludford expressed a willingness to continue working with peers from across the House on issues they agree on, but a Labour source predicted "residual tensions" and a lack of interest in organizing a "progressive consensus summer drinks" gathering.

In the current election, defence is not a top priority for most political parties, with opinion polls showing it ranks low among electorate concerns. This is partly due to public fatigue from military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya. Despite the world becoming more dangerous and unstable, many European nations, including the UK, have been cutting their armed forces. The UK's regular Army is being reduced from 102,000 to 82,000, and the Royal Navy and RAF have seen significant reductions in their fleets and fast jet squadrons. The UK has also fallen from being the fourth biggest spender on defence to sixth place, and is unlikely to meet the NATO target of spending 2% of GDP on defence. All major parties are promising further cuts to the budget deficit, which could lead to more defence cuts. The Conservatives are committed to replacing Trident and increasing the defence equipment budget, while Labour and the Liberal Democrats have been cautious. The future of the UK's nuclear deterrent and the manning levels for new aircraft carriers are also areas of concern.

The passage discusses the ongoing legal issues surrounding the transfer of Neymar from Santos to Barcelona. Despite Barcelona's insistence that they had not committed any offense, a judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. The club has now made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential tax-related issues, though they maintain that their original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. The transfer of Neymar, which cost Barcelona £48.6m, has been a significant financial transaction, with the total cost to the club, including wages, agents' fees, and the latest tax payment, amounting to £106.8m. Neymar has performed well for Barcelona, scoring seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

The passage describes the tragic death of Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, who was a passenger in a van hit by a Mazda Premacy driven by Albert Kenneth Newman, an elderly man who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Both Michael and Albert died in the accident. Michael's family and colleagues expressed their grief and called for stricter measures for older drivers, suggesting that retired people should undergo regular driving tests and medical examinations. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) currently requires drivers over 70 to fill out a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses, but does not conduct medical or driving tests. Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older drivers to maintain their independence and driving safety.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence, with many women reporting debilitating side effects. Two members of the original review group resigned in protest over a perceived watered-down report. Independent expert Alison Britton, a professor of healthcare and medical law, will examine the final report to assess the review process and identify lessons for the future. The report concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended patients be given a range of treatment options and information to make informed choices. It also advised mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for an all-out ban, the recommendations will continue to be implemented. The health secretary noted that the UK regulatory body, the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency, has the authority to ban the procedures. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the controversial final report and acknowledged the difficulty of her task. Several panel members, including Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, resigned due to dismay and disgust over the report's publication. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have undergone mesh or tape implants, with some suffering painful and debilitating complications, leading to legal actions against health boards and manufacturers.

The passage discusses the breaking of a 25-year-old UK indoor 5000m record by Laura Muir, who achieved a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. Muir's record, set by Sheila McColgan in 1992, was broken by 14 seconds. McColgan, who had initially expressed concerns about whether Muir's race met all the criteria set by UK Athletics for record-breaking attempts, confirmed that Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's potential, suggesting she could run even faster and achieve world-class status, but noted that Muir needs to improve her race tactics to start winning medals.

The passage describes the results of a show-jumping competition at the Rio Olympics. Germany's Ingrid Jung won the gold medal aboard Sam, who was a late replacement for Fischertakinou, who contracted an infection. France's Nicolas Astier took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, finished 12th despite a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase. Fox-Pitt, 47, had competed just 10 months after being placed in an induced coma following a fall. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift. The passage also invites readers to visit fan parks during the Rio Olympics to meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse.

The passage describes a tennis match where Andy Murray, a 30-year-old Briton, defeated 29th-seeded Fognini in four sets. The match lasted two hours and 39 minutes, with Murray clinching the match at 20:57 BST. Despite Fognini having five set points, Murray won five consecutive games to secure his place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will face Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also reached the second week for the first time with a win over Maria Sakkari of Greece. The match was described as tense and up and down, with Murray expressing that he didn't feel he played his best tennis but managed to win. Fognini's performance was marked by both his talent and temperament, with a notable incident where he was penalized a point for a visible obscenity. Despite this, Murray showed his fighting qualities and won the match.

The passage details a court case in Dungiven where paramedics were called to Joe's Bar at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 due to a sudden death. The police found several people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was being served until 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months and charged Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. O'Neill, the license holder, was fined £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000. The judge expressed concern over O'Neill's "appalling record" and the poor management of the premises.

The passage discusses Mike Nesbitt's speech launching the Ulster Unionists' manifesto, 'Real Partnership.' Nesbitt emphasized the importance of partnership over domination and addressed the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle, suggesting the election should be a referendum on how it was handled. He denied any regrets about his comments and reaffirmed his stance on voting for Ulster Unionists and supporting candidates who will act in the community's best interest. Nesbitt expressed confidence in his position and the support from unionist areas, focusing on the manifesto's key points, including tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing infrastructure projects, and standing up for the LGBT community. The manifesto also includes a section on 'Cleaning Up Stormont,' highlighting issues of incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption. Nesbitt's comments have drawn attention, and he must hope his message resonates more than the controversy surrounding his remarks about transferring to the SDLP.

The passage discusses a motion by Justice Minister Claire Sugden to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales regarding posthumous pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. Dubbed 'Turing's Law', this law will also allow living men convicted of such offences to apply for a pardon. The motion, expected to be approved by the assembly, will cover both posthumous and living gay and bisexual men. The minister has secured executive agreement to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon these convictions. The goal is to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as in England and Wales, and to address past wrongs in the criminal justice system.

The passage details the achievements of Laura Muir, a 23-year-old athlete from Kinross, who set a new Scottish record in the 1500m race by finishing second with a time of 4 minutes, 19.12 seconds, just behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This performance surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and placed Muir second on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who is currently a veterinary student, expressed her satisfaction with the achievement and her excitement about the upcoming British trials in Birmingham, where she aims to secure a spot for the Olympics in Rio.
The passage provides a brief overview of a collection of images showcasing the 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as "most excellent" for water quality.

The passage discusses the poisoning of former Russian spy Alexander Litvinenko in 2006. Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that the suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, had no personal motive to kill Litvinenko. He suggested that the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot and had strong reasons to wish him dead. The UK officials believe the two suspects poisoned Litvinenko with a fatal dose of polonium-210 during a meeting in London. Litvinenko died in hospital nearly three weeks later. Horwell argued that the involvement of polonium in the crime indicates Russian state participation. However, he clarified that this does not mean Russian President Vladimir Putin was involved or gave the order. Litvinenko defected to the UK in 2000, accusing the FSB of murdering political opponents and of corruption, which could be seen as "akin to treachery." He also mentioned Litvinenko's personal attacks on Putin. Horwell noted that Litvinenko had been poisoned twice before his death, leading to great suffering and eventually his demise. The risk to the general public in London from polonium radiation remains unknown, and the two attacks on Litvinenko were described as an outrage. The suspects left a "trail of polonium" and had no credible answer to the scientific evidence against them. Despite the force's desire to try the suspects for murder, this is now unlikely due to their failure to extradite them. Former Soviet army officer Kovtun was criticized by inquiry chairman Sir Robert Owen for failing to give evidence, and the inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

The passage discusses the appointment of Steve Smith as the captain of the Australian cricket team, both in the one-day and Twenty20 formats, in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch. Smith, at 26, has already led the side in three Tests against India last summer. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith, describing him as a "fine young man with extraordinary talent" and a "highly regarded" player. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain, despite a history of disciplinary issues, and has matured into an important senior figure in the team. The passage also mentions that Clarke, 34, confirmed his retirement after his side's heavy defeat by England in the Ashes. Smith will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval, which starts on 20 August.

The passage discusses the stance of a political leader, Mr. Farron, on LGBT-plus rights and equal marriage. He expresses his passion for LGBT-plus rights and his commitment to defending equal marriage, which he considers a top priority. Despite his liberal views, he avoids directly answering whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead stating that "my firm belief is we are all sinners." Mr. Farron was also asked about his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill, which aimed to protect gay people from discrimination. He clarified that he is a liberal and supports equality, and he is in favor of extending marital rights to transgender people. He mentions the spousal veto, which requires the consent of a partner for a marriage to continue after a person changes gender, and states that he is in favor of equal access to marriage for all people, regardless of their sexuality.

The passage describes a significant change in the local economy of Newcastle and the North East, where French-based Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. In response to this closure, Accord Healthcare, a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, has announced plans to take over the site for its pharmaceutical production. The company aims to hire many of the former Sanofi employees, which Accord's spokesman believes will have an "extremely positive" impact on the area. The leader of Newcastle City Council, Councillor Nick Forbes, welcomed the news, stating that it strengthens the region's reputation as a hub for science and healthcare. Accord Healthcare develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to approximately 60 countries worldwide, and the move is expected to bring a significant boost to the local economy through the creation of highly skilled jobs and long-term investment.

The passage discusses the departures of Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland from the local authority. Richard Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract on Friday. Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the leader of the opposition SNP group, suggests that these departures reflect the council's inability to retain senior staff and predicts further departures in the coming months. The council's chief executive, Angela Scott, thanked the trio for their "dedication and professionalism."

The passage discusses the situation of English rider Martin, who crashed during this year's TT and faced mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. Martin initially told MCN that he was quitting road racing, but later clarified on Facebook that he was not giving up on racing or road racing but had no plans to race on Hondas this year. He did not race at the North West 200 due to a team-mate's crash and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as a "bloody disaster" and stated that the bike was not competitive, leading to his withdrawal from the event. He expressed a desire to race classics and oddball events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP lost the presidential poll last month for the first time. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May, after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's decline was reinforced by results from Saturday's elections for governors and state assemblies, with the party losing key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as control of Adamawa, one of the states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. The PDP failed to secure a national spread of votes, performing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. Most states in the north, along with Lagos, went to the APC. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were marred by violence in some areas due to ethnic differences and rivalry, but overall, they were more peaceful than in previous years, suggesting that Nigeria's democracy is maturing.

The passage discusses environmental concerns raised by the US-based environmental lobby group Mighty against Olam, a Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Temasek, a Singapore state-owned investment company. Mighty accuses Olam and Temasek of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to the haze caused by agricultural fires in Indonesia. Olam buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and claims to have a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" compliance policy. However, Mighty's report suggests that Olam could be unwittingly encouraging unsustainable practices and creating a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies." Temasek, as the majority stakeholder in Olam, could be linked to the haze affecting Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia if the claims are proven. The report also highlights concerns in Gabon, where Olam is accused of bulldozing rainforests to establish palm oil plantations. Olam and Temasek have dismissed the allegations, emphasizing their support for no-burn policies and the company's strict sourcing and compliance policies.
The passage describes a restaurant that started serving puppy platters after a new law was introduced, which allows dogs to eat at restaurants, but only outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri's fitness is uncertain, having only played from the bench in the last two games. David Nugent is a potential returnee after missing a recent match due to a groin injury. Jacob Butterfield is also in the running for a starting spot, having scored a late equalizer from the bench against Huddersfield.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator has lifted the ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version. The ban was initially imposed in 2012 following the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims." YouTube has denied claims that the authorities can filter content, and the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) has confirmed that all internet service providers have been directed to open access to YouTube. However, Google has agreed to restrict access to offending material upon request from the PTA. Despite the lifting of the ban, some activists are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms agreed between Google and the government.

The passage discusses the ongoing election to replace the long-standing president of Fifa, Sepp Blatter. Domenico Scala, who heads up Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing a conflict of interest claim due to his Swiss-Italian nationality, which is shared by one of the five presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. The Liberian Football Association (LFA) boss, Musa Bility, has threatened to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw from the committee by Thursday. Bility cites Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations, which states that any member of the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee with a conflict of interest must be replaced. Scala has defended his position, arguing that having the same nationality as a candidate does not constitute a conflict of interest and that the relevant regulations do not support Bility's claim. The election, scheduled for 26 February, will be held at Fifa's headquarters in Zurich and will be decided by Fifa's 209 members. The candidates are Prince Ali of Jordan, Gianni Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale.

The passage describes the tragic deaths of Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, who were working at Harford Attachments in Spar Road when they were killed shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. The men were believed to be working in a paint-spraying area when they were involved in a flashover explosion, which is caused by a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source, resulting in a fire-ball effect. The bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. Detective Chief Inspector Paul Durham stated that significant progress has been made with forensic inquiries and obtaining witness statements. The Health and Safety Executive has also confirmed that its inspectors and electrical safety experts will be gathering evidence.

The passage discusses the resolution of two significant issues for Tunisia and Morocco in relation to the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia faced expulsion from the tournament after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial penalty call in their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea in 2015. However, an apology to Caf resolved the issue, and Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was secured. Morocco, which was initially banned from the 2017 qualifying draw, was able to enter after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned the ban. The Moroccan FA chief, Fouzi Lekjaa, expressed optimism about the future of African football, emphasizing that the impact of the ban was minimal. The passage also provides details about the 2017 Nations Cup group stages, with Tunisia facing Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, and Morocco facing Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

The passage describes a mass fracas that occurred in the 95th minute of a game between Manchester City and Chelsea at Etihad Stadium, where Chelsea won 3-1. As a result, Manchester City's forward Sergio Aguero and midfielder Fernandinho were sent off. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, specifically for a high and late challenge on Chelsea defender David Luiz, which was his second dismissal for such conduct this season. Fernandinho was also sent off for clashing with Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas during the scuffle, and he will serve a three-match ban. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd aimed at improving early detection of cancer. The scheme focuses on families with a history of cancer who do not show any clear symptoms. The Welsh health system has been criticized for delayed diagnosis, with only 35% of patients with "better prognosis" receiving a diagnosis in the Cwm Taf area. The pilot aims to encourage families to undergo more frequent screenings and to provide a more personalized approach to diagnosis. The scheme is part of a broader plan by the Abertawe Bro Morgannwg Health Board to improve cancer detection. Dr. Gareth Davies, from Cancer Support Wales, supports the scheme, emphasizing the importance of early detection and personalized care. The scheme is expected to significantly impact the lives of cancer patients by ensuring timely and accurate diagnosis.

The passage describes England's decisive victory over Pakistan in the second Test match at Old Trafford, which allowed England to level the four-match series. England scored 589-8 declared in their first innings and 173-1 declared in their second innings, resulting in a second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, who was promoted to number three for this series, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket. Alastair Cook, the captain, scored 105 and 76 not out. The passage highlights Root's improvement and the overall quality of England's performance, while Pakistan's spirit was described as broken. Only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passed 50 in the first two Tests, and Misbah expressed disappointment and a commitment to improve.

The passage discusses the British and Irish Lions' preparations for their tour to New Zealand, led by head coach Warren Gatland. Interim coach Rob Howley has been named part of the backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will again take on head coach responsibilities, having led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. He expresses excitement and the added responsibility of representing his country overseas. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is in the process of appointing assistant coaches to support McBryde, with discussions ongoing for the summer tour. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips expects to confirm the full management team next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team, providing valuable experience and inspiration for both coaches and players.

In a dramatic turn of events at the KCOM Stadium, Hull City secured their first league win since August 20th, defeating Southampton 2-1. The game began promisingly for Southampton, with Charlie Austin scoring a penalty in the sixth minute, giving the visitors an early lead. However, Hull's fortunes changed dramatically in the 70th and 71st minutes when Robert Snodgrass, introduced as a substitute, scored twice, first with a goal from Sam Clucas' cross and then with an assist for Michael Dawson's goal. Southampton's push for an equalizer was thwarted by Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall, who made several crucial saves, including a remarkable goalline clearance in the final minute of added time. Snodgrass's performance was particularly noteworthy, showcasing his determination and skill despite his swollen ankle, which had healed overnight. The win ended Hull's six-game losing streak but left them still in the bottom three of the league.

The crash occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 near Thornton, Lincolnshire. A local motorcyclist was killed in the collision, while the tractor driver was not injured. Lincolnshire Police have not released further details about the motorcyclist but are appealing for witnesses to come forward. The road was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

The passage describes a political crisis in Macedonia, triggered by covert recordings released by opposition leader Zoran Zaev in February 2015. These recordings allegedly show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder, along with corruption at the highest levels of government, including mismanagement of funds and dubious criminal prosecutions. President Ivanov, in a televised address, cancelled an investigation into these claims, stating he wanted to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections in June. His decision was condemned by both the opposition and EU officials, who argued it was illegal and undermined the rule of law. The EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn warned that the move could jeopardize Macedonia's EU membership ambitions.

Swansea City Football Club is currently without a manager after Bob Bradley was sacked. Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Saturday's match against Bournemouth. The club is keen to appoint a new manager as soon as possible, with Paul Clement, the former Derby manager, being the first choice. The club is concerned about the possibility of relegation and the difficulty of returning to the Premier League if they do go down. Swansea was promoted to the Premier League in 2011 and has a reputation for well-run, exciting football. However, they have lost their way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, and Curtis believes the club has not been the same since. He emphasizes the importance of staying up for the club and the local area.

The passage discusses a football match between Dagenham & Redbridge (Daggers) and Leyton Orient (O's) in League One. Dagenham needed a victory to keep their survival hopes alive, but Leyton Orient took the lead with two goals from Jay Simpson. However, Armand Gnanduillet scored the winning goal for Dagenham, relegating them and keeping Leyton Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham reached the Football League for the first time in 2007 but now returns to the National League under manager John Still, who previously led the club from the Conference to League One. The Daggers have the worst goal difference in League Two and have struggled offensively, with Jamie Cureton scoring nine goals this season compared to 20 in the 2014-15 campaign. Still is committed to helping the Daggers gain promotion next season. Leyton Orient's interim manager, Andy Hessenthaler, emphasized the importance of winning games to secure a play-off spot, despite losing two managers this season.

The passage discusses the appointment of Steven Gerrard as a youth coach at Liverpool, his former club. Gerrard, who retired as a player in November after a 19-year career, will return to Liverpool in February. Jürgen Klopp, the current Liverpool manager, praised Gerrard's appointment, noting that Gerrard has expressed a desire to become a manager in the future. Klopp emphasized the importance of understanding Gerrard's aspirations and his readiness to learn. Gerrard's playing career included winning the Champions League, Uefa Cup, FA Cup, and League Cup on three occasions. He had previously been linked with the manager's job at MK Dons but felt the opportunity at Liverpool was too good to pass up. Additionally, Gerrard is working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, which is necessary to manage in the Premier League.

The passage describes a football match where Morton defeated Alloa. Morton scored first with a goal from McManus, followed by a goal from Ross Forbes. Alloa managed to score once through Kyle McAusland, but Morton regained their lead with goals from McManus and Denny Johnstone.

The passage discusses the findings of Ofsted, the Office for Standards in Education, regarding unregulated schools in Birmingham. Ofsted has discovered three unregulated schools in Birmingham that are now closed, with the potential for the owners to face up to 51 weeks in jail. Sir Michael Wilshaw, the Chief Inspector of Schools in England, expressed shock at the squalid conditions found in these schools. The investigation has visited 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, with three in Birmingham being closed and their owners under investigation. Wilshaw is concerned that these cases represent only a fraction of the problem and that children are at risk of abuse or radicalization. The government is considering stricter regulations for places teaching more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Currently, any place teaching more than 20 hours a week must register as a school. Some centers, described as part-time education centers or "flexi schools," are operating legally to support home-educated children, but some are suspected of operating illegal schools. Ofsted and the government are concerned about these centers taking advantage of the legal right to home educate. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, and the education secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools. The consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is set to open as the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. The distillery, led by Kate Macinnes, aims to make the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence." Lilliard Gin operates on a smaller scale compared to other distilleries in development, with a small production still fitting into a cowshed. The gin will capture the local flavors of the Teviot valley, reflecting the Borders' terroir. The distillery is a natural complement to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the same site, and the name Lilliard Gin is inspired by a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

Harry Whitlam was killed by Gary Green, who was driving a tractor on private land. Green was over two times the legal alcohol limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before driving. The court heard that Green had been jailed for 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her hope that the family could remember the good times they shared and that Harry's life would be remembered more than just the day of the accident.

The passage discusses the appeal of Luis Suarez, the Uruguay striker, against a four-month ban imposed by FIFA for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) upheld the ban but reduced it to eight games, allowing Suarez to train and play in friendly matches. The CAS ruled that preventing Suarez from participating in any football-related activities was "excessive," as it would impact his performance after the suspension. Suarez can now attend matches, take part in promotional activities, and play in friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. His legal team argued that FIFA had "misapplied its own rules," and the decision was seen as a balance between the player's interests and the need for proportionate sanctions.

The passage describes a competition where Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won against Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. They trained for a week and were pushed hard by the Lithuanians. The competitors had to complete a 380-metre course that included hurdling over haystacks, climbing a steep slope, and avoiding water pistols. The race allowed all combinations of competitors, including men carrying men and women carrying women. Richard and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses the changes in job roles at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) following the scrapping of the paper car tax disc system in October 2014. Stephen Hammond, a minister, addressed concerns about job losses in a letter to Mike Hedges, an AM from Swansea East. He assured that while the introduction of a direct debit scheme might lead to a reduction in refunds and changes in job roles, any necessary reductions in staff will be managed through redeployment to other areas of the business. Hedges welcomed the minister's assurances, noting that while the changes will reduce job opportunities, the advantages of the new system and the commitment to redeployment will provide comfort to DVLA employees.

The passage discusses Hungary's stance on EU interference with its domestic policies, particularly regarding asylum seekers, NGOs, and a higher education law. Hungary's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Peter Szijjarto, stated that Hungary would not backtrack on these issues, as they are considered national competence. Poland has pledged to veto any EU moves to strip Hungary of its voting rights. The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers and NGOs, as well as a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University, founded by George Soros. Thousands of Hungarians have protested against these laws. The EU has threatened action if there are no positive developments, but Hungary remains firm in its stance.

The passage details the casting and production of a live-action adaptation of the 1991 animated film "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens playing the Beast and Luke Evans as the villainous Gaston. Josh Gad, known for voicing Olaf in "Frozen," will voice Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, the father of Belle, and Emma Thompson will voice Mrs. Potts, the housekeeper magically transformed into a teapot, originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and is set to begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May, with a release date of 17 March 2017 in US cinemas.

The passage describes the passing of Adrian Gill, a prominent journalist and columnist for the Sunday Times. Gill, who had been diagnosed with a wide range of cancers, was known for his witty, fearless, and compassionate writing style. He was described as the "heart and soul" of the Sunday Times, and his death has left a significant void in the journalism community. Gill's writing often sparked controversy, with notable incidents including his description of the Welsh as "dark, ugly little trolls" and his critical reviews of various locations and individuals. Despite his controversial opinions, Gill was widely respected for his intelligence, compassion, and unique writing style. He overcame dyslexia to become a successful writer, and his career included stints at Tatler and the Sunday Times. Gill's personal life was marked by two marriages and four children, and he recently engaged to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, after being diagnosed with cancer.

The passage describes an incident where Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, also known as Amraa, was attacked in Ulan Bator, the capital of Mongolia. According to Russian news reports, he was struck over the head with a bottle and kicked in the face. The Russian embassy, however, stated that the reports were "distorted" and that they were investigating the incident. Sukhbaatar, who is the lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was performing in a red deel robe embroidered with a swastika, a traditional symbol in Mongolia that pre-dates Hitler. His father, Sevjidiin Sukhbaatar, confirmed that his son spent about 10 days in a coma and was seriously injured. The Russian official accused of the attack has not been identified, and the case is under investigation by the police. The swastika is a traditional symbol in Mongolia, believed to have originated in India and used as a symbol of eternity centuries before the Third Reich. The incident has sparked discussions about the use of the swastika in Mongolia and the potential for far-right groups to adopt it.

Plane Stupid, an action group, protested against the airport's expansion plans by staging a demonstration on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. The protesters were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. They are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. Following the incident, the Metropolitan Police announced that they would review security at the airport.

In the passage, it is described that Glamorgan's total was primarily driven by Nick Selman's 101-run innings, his second first-class century. Despite being dropped early, Selman's performance was a welcome return to form after a series of low scores. Matt Taylor and Craig Miles, the seamers, ensured regular wickets, contributing to the overall success of the bowling attack. Aneurin Donald's 36-run contribution was the next best, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten helped Glamorgan secure a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire's innings was focused on survival, with the match ending evenly balanced by the end of the day. The passage also mentions that Glamorgan is being led by Michael Hogan for the first time, as Jacques Rudolph is absent due to a neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after he made threats to murder police officers. He chatted online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee, leading to concerns about a planned ambush. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. He claimed he planned to make a false report to the police so that officers would come to the scene, where he would then shoot them on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made while he was drunk. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody, noting his previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. Hughes's legal team stated he did not intend to kill himself and would not have carried out the threats. North Wales Police were particularly concerned because Hughes was on bail for firearms offenses, which he was later cleared of. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling to those in need.

The passage describes a cricket match where Yorkshire, after being reduced to 8-2, managed to post a score of 255-7, with key contributions from Davies and Ben Foakes, who shared a stand of 130. Yorkshire's run-chase was significantly hindered by a three-wicket burst in nine balls from Stuart Meaker, which included the dismissals of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan making 68, Yorkshire were all out for 236. The match was a crucial one for Yorkshire, who had lost to Durham in the T20 Blast semi-finals the previous weekend and were aiming to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002. Despite a strong start, Yorkshire's chase was ultimately unsuccessful, with the bowlers performing exceptionally well.

A 56ft converted trawler was 6 miles west of South Stack when its crew radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST. The boat's pump was overwhelmed by incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew provided assistance by placing a pump on board and towing the vessel to safety at Holyhead.

The passage discusses the athletic career of Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir. Muir, who is currently 24 years old, has achieved notable success, finishing fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m events at the World Athletics Championships. However, she has decided not to participate in the Commonwealth Games in April 2018 due to her veterinary medicine studies, which will keep her busy until May. Muir is committed to completing her final year at university, which takes precedence over her athletic commitments. Despite her absence from the Commonwealth Games, Muir remains optimistic about her future in athletics, expressing confidence in her ability to compete in at least two, and potentially three, more Olympics. She also considers the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target for her next competition.

In his BBC Sport column, football pundit Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's struggles in repeating their title challenge from the previous season. He highlights the loss of key players like Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge, who scored 52 of Liverpool's 101 Premier League goals last season, and the inadequacy of their current frontline players. Savage also criticizes Liverpool's defense, which has not improved despite significant investments in players like Mamadou Sakho and Dejan Lovren. He suggests that Liverpool's defensive issues stem from a lack of a clear leader and a goalkeeper who does not command the box effectively. Savage predicts that Liverpool will need a significant improvement to compete against Chelsea, who are currently on a different level in the Premier League. Additionally, he discusses Steven Gerrard's mental and physical battle to secure a long-term future with Liverpool, emphasizing his importance to the team and his determination to overcome past setbacks.

The passage describes a £45 million educational facility to be built in Kilmarnock, which will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus after the renowned Scottish writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. The council leader, Douglas Reid, expressed delight in honoring McIlvanney, noting his passion for education. McIlvanney, who died in December 2010, was a prolific author, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," and wrote notable works such as the Laidlaw trilogy and Glasgow-based novels like Docherty and The Big Man. He was also a significant poet, journalist, and broadcaster, contributing to political and sporting life in Scotland through his columns and TV programs.

A town area near the swimming pool was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon due to a sea mine spotted on the river. The mine is believed to be British, dating from the 1940s or 1950s. An exclusion zone remains in force, affecting three streets and residents within 500m of the mine. The Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit is handling the mine, which has deteriorated, making it unclear how much explosive material it still contains. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, and there was no immediate danger to the community. The operation caused some disruption to ferry services and required residents to stay indoors near walls and avoid going outside.

UK Sport has announced a reduction in funding for several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby. Cycling, which contributed 12 medals to Team GB in Rio, has seen its funding cut by over £4 million to £25.98 million. Badminton England, which was set a target of winning a medal in Rio and earned a bronze in the men's doubles, has had its funding removed entirely. This decision has been met with strong criticism from Adrian Christy, the chief executive of Badminton England, who described it as "catastrophic" and vowed to fight for the sport's future. Judo, which also achieved a bronze medal, has seen its funding increased slightly. UK Sport's CEO, Liz Nicholl, explained that the decision to cut funding was not taken lightly and that the organization had to prioritize to protect and enhance medal potential. Sports minister Tracey Crouch praised UK Sport's approach to elite sport, noting its success in Beijing, London, and Rio, and expressed confidence in the ambition to win more medals in Tokyo. UK Sport is also considering funding for five new Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020, with a total of £9 million still to be allocated.

The passage discusses the demolition of three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff area to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. English Heritage objected to the scale of the development, which is in a designated conservation area, arguing it would cause "severe harm." However, councillors voted seven to three in favor, citing the need to boost tourism and improve living conditions for older residents. The project, led by The East Cliff Project LLP, will result in a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments in a nine-storey and seven-storey building. Despite 246 letters of support, 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society opposed the demolition, emphasizing the historic character of the area.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally attacked by Jake Vallely in Brecon. The jury cleared Vallely's friend Aaeron Evans of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. CCTV footage showed Boyd being punched, dragged to the ground, and beaten to death outside a bar called The Cellar. Vallely, who had been on a seven-hour drinking binge, boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. He was sentenced on 8 December. The community of Brecon was shocked by the act, and Boyd's family described him as an "all-rounder" with a promising career ahead.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by mutual agreement following an election day error where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and Travers expressed his belief in the council's ongoing growth and transformation in a statement. The council acknowledged Travers' valuable contribution during his tenure. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over until longer-term arrangements are made. The council apologized for the issues and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. However, some voters questioned the fairness of the election results. The council's review, which will conclude by the end of May, will examine the appropriateness of arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum.

In the football match between Gateshead and Wrexham, Gateshead emerged victorious with a final score of 2-1. The game began with Josh Gillies scoring the first goal for Gateshead with a fine free-kick, putting the Tynesiders ahead. Wrexham equalized before half-time through Sean Newton's set-piece. However, Ryan Bowman's header from Craig Baxter's cross in the second half secured the win for Gateshead. Manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's improvement in the second half, noting better passing and a more effective attack. Wrexham's manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment, highlighting the team's inability to capitalize on their chances in the second half.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of individuals aged 60 and above in 96 countries. Norway ranks first, while Afghanistan is at the bottom, followed by Mozambique.

The passage discusses the OneWeb project, a venture by Airbus to build a large-scale satellite constellation for global broadband internet coverage. The network will initially consist of at least 600 satellites, with the potential to expand to over 2,000. The primary goal is to provide internet access to every corner of the globe, with a particular focus on connecting schools. To achieve this, Airbus and OneWeb are adopting new manufacturing methods similar to those used in car and plane production, aiming to produce satellites at a high volume and low cost, with each unit costing less than a million dollars. The first assembly line has been inaugurated in Toulouse, France, with two more lines planned for a new factory in Florida. The first 10 satellites are scheduled for launch in April 2020, with subsequent batches following into orbit. The project will require the largest rocket campaign in history, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles booked to launch clusters of 32-36 satellites into orbit at 1,200km above the Earth. OneWeb has already raised $1.7 billion in equity and is in talks to secure the necessary loans for the project. The company is registered in the UK's Channel Islands and will work closely with the UK Space Agency. OneWeb is committed to setting new standards in debris mitigation, aiming to de-orbit redundant satellites within two years and ensuring their safe re-entry into the Earth's atmosphere. The passage also notes that while the new manufacturing approaches may disrupt the satellite industry, they are not applicable to all platforms, as some space missions will still require specialized, high-cost solutions.

The passage discusses the impact of the UK government's recent spending review on public expenditure in Scotland. Mr. Swinney, a Scottish government minister, argues that the review has placed "unprecedented pressure" on public spending north of the border, with the Scottish government's discretionary budget expected to be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. He claims that the UK government's Chancellor, George Osborne, has imposed real terms cuts on Scotland every year from 2010 until 2020, with more than £1bn of cuts still to come by the end of the decade. Despite these challenges, the Scottish government is committed to protecting key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service. In response, a spokesman for the UK government's Scotland Office emphasizes that the Scottish government will have £390m more in spending available to them next year, rising to £750m if underspend is included, and that the stability of the UK economy means the block grant will be almost £30bn. The passage also includes comments from Labour's public services spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, who calls for a long-term budget and a real alternative to austerity.

The passage discusses the lack of suitable toilet facilities for people with severe disabilities and their carers, who often face significant challenges when leaving the house. These individuals may require two carers or a hoist to assist with transferring onto a bench for changing, which is not typically available in standard accessible toilets. The Changing Places toilets, with their enhanced facilities and more space, are designed to meet these specific needs. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but campaigners are pushing for these to be made compulsory in larger buildings such as shopping centers, cinemas, and leisure facilities. Lorna Fillingham, mother of a six-year-old with severe disabilities, has started a petition to make Changing Places guidelines compulsory, emphasizing the stress and guilt she feels when faced with the lack of suitable facilities. The psychological impact on families, as described by Alison Beevers, can be devastating, leading to a sense of being overlooked and undervalued. However, there are positive examples, such as Arsenal Football Club, which has successfully installed a Changing Places toilet, demonstrating the benefits and the importance of making such facilities a standard requirement in new buildings.

A group of Italian consumers' organizations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging that the company forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's defends its practices, stating that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees and that this approach has been successful for many years. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and various European unions, including the Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union in the UK, support the complaint, arguing that McDonald's abuse of its dominant market position harms franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission has agreed to study the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are founded. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to long-term contracts and that they lease premises at above-market rates, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to those owned directly by McDonald's. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and the company received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

The passage describes a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign began with a hashtag #prayforjosh on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is a pastoral staff member. The hashtag quickly went viral, with the initial post being shared 948 times and seen by over 79,000 people. A mystery donor paid for a massive billboard with the hashtag to be placed in Holywood by the A2. The campaign has received support from people all over the world, including Josh's classmates at Bangor Grammar School.

The UK government has announced the closure of Brecon Barracks, a historic military base in Brecon, Wales, which has been in operation since 1805. The decision has been strongly criticized by Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies, who launched a petition against the closure. Davies highlighted the barracks' significant role in British military history, noting that it has been home to troops who fought in various conflicts, including the Zulu War. He expressed concerns about the impact on the local economy, particularly the high unemployment rates in the Brecon area, and the potential damage to the town's thriving military tourism industry. The closure is part of a broader reorganization of UK military buildings and the resettlement of regiments, with the creation of a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan. Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire, which was previously announced for closure in 2013, will now shut in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025. The Shadow Defence Secretary, Nia Griffith, acknowledged the need for restructuring but warned that the closures could lead to "gnawing uncertainty" for many local residents.

The passage discusses the complexities of the UK's fishing industry in the context of Brexit. It highlights that fishing regions around the UK voted strongly for leaving the EU, and the Lords review warns that these communities could be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been criticized by the industry, leading to a desire for control over UK waters post-Brexit. However, the Lords report notes that the UK's fishing industry is a low priority for the government but must not be overlooked. The report also points out that many commercial fish stocks are shared with other EU coastal states, and the UK's fish exports are primarily to the EU, while much of the fish consumed in the UK is imported from EU states. The report suggests that continued market access to the EU may require more access to UK waters by EU member states. The Lords recommend retaining elements of the CFP post-Brexit, including scientifically based catch limits and international cooperation. The potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland is a concern. Despite these challenges, the fishing industry remains optimistic about Brexit, seeing it as an opportunity for better management and control over UK waters. The government aims to ensure British companies have maximum freedom to trade and operate in the single market while reviewing fisheries management for fairer access, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks exposing extensive US surveillance activities. The US National Security Agency (NSA) has access to a vast amount of personal data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The NSA also requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call duration, location, and phone numbers of both parties. The Prism program, which allows the NSA to access servers of major technology companies like Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, and Facebook, has been criticized for its potential invasion of privacy. The US government argues that these measures are necessary for national security, but experts question their true scope and legality. Different countries have varying data protection laws, and the US Patriot Act of 2001 has given American authorities new powers over European data stored in the US. The EU is concerned about the implications of Prism for its citizens, and privacy campaigners are alarmed by the potential for widespread surveillance.

The passage discusses the establishment of OpenAI, a venture backed by prominent figures such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. The primary goal of OpenAI is to conduct research in artificial intelligence (AI) with a focus on achieving a "positive human impact," without the constraints of financial obligations. The passage highlights concerns from scientists, including Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, who have warned that advances in AI could pose a significant threat to humanity. However, the venture aims to ensure that AI is developed in a way that benefits humanity as a whole, emphasizing its potential to enhance society while minimizing the risk of negative consequences. OpenAI's statement on its website emphasizes that AI should be an extension of individual human wills and should be distributed as broadly and evenly as possible, safely. The venture has pledged $1 billion, with only a small fraction expected to be spent in the near future.

The passage describes L/Bdr Parkinson, a Doncaster-based individual who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. Despite his injuries, which included a brain injury that affected his speech, he has shown remarkable resilience and determination. He carried the Olympic torch on 26 June, walking for nearly half an hour with the help of an assistant, and has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, though the site limits personal pages to 5,000 friends. His mother, Diane, noted the overwhelming support and how it has significantly boosted his morale. Parkinson spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, and he uses his platform to raise money for military charities and as a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. The passage also mentions the Facebook guidance that if someone receives a large number of friend requests, they may be considered a public figure and should consider creating a page instead of a profile or using subscription to manage updates.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the United States was 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, which remained unchanged from the previous three years. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. The Gini index, a measure of income inequality, increased by 1.6%, marking the first annual rise since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance dropped to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty in the US reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

The passage discusses the signing of 25-year-old Jos Buttler to Lancashire County Cricket Club, where he will remain until 2019. Buttler, a short-format specialist, has achieved notable milestones, including scoring England's three fastest ODI centuries, with a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praises Buttler's talent and his role in Lancashire's T20 Blast final victory at Edgbaston. Giles also highlights Buttler's positive influence in the dressing room and his international experience, which benefits the squad. Buttler, who has played in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour, awaiting potential preservation or recycling. Bidders had until 23 January to express interest, with viewings scheduled for late February and March. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, supports UK recyclers but also advocates for at least one frigate to be saved, preferably for a reef and diving attraction to boost tourism. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer.

The passage describes the ongoing racial and political tensions in Fiji since 1987, which have led to instability and international isolation. Key events include:

1. **1987 Coup**: An indigenous Fijian coup overthrew an Indian-dominated coalition, leading to the introduction and subsequent withdrawal of a constitution that enshrined indigenous Fijian political supremacy.
2. **2000 Coup**: A coup led by businessman George Speight resulted in the hostage situation of the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister and his cabinet, causing significant economic and reputational damage.
3. **2006 Military Takeover**: A bloodless military coup in 2006 marked Fiji's fourth coup in 20 years, exacerbating tensions and divisions.
4. **2009 Commonwealth Suspension**: Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in September 2009 due to its lack of progress towards democracy, the second such suspension in the organization's history.
5. **2012 Free Elections Agreement**: In 2012, the government agreed to hold free elections in 2014, which led to the restoration of full diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand.
6. **2014 Elections and Commonwealth Re-instatement**: Following the elections, the Commonwealth re-instated Fiji as a member.

Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with indigenous Fijians now forming a small overall majority. The two groups have minimal mixing, and informal segregation is deeply ingrained in society. The economy, reliant on sugar and tourism, faces persistent trade and budget deficits, making Fiji one of the world's largest per capita recipients of aid.

The passage discusses Syria's efforts to comply with the international agreement to destroy its chemical weapons, which it missed a deadline for. Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, blamed the delay on attacks on shipments of weapons from Damascus to the port of Latakia. He also criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of the Syrian government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, insisting that the government is defending its people against terrorist attacks. The Syrian government denied reports that rebels had seized Aleppo's central prison, but the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and other sources claim that rebels now control the prison, which holds at least 3,000 detainees. The passage also mentions that Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, and the US is concerned that the destruction process is falling behind schedule. Russia has set a new deadline for the transfer of chemical weapons to the coast by 1 March.

The passage discusses the 2013 Booker Prize shortlist, which includes Mukherjee's "The Lives Of Others," Howard Jacobson's "J," Ali Smith's "How To Be Both," Joshua Ferris's "To Rise Again at a Decent Hour," Karen Joy Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves," and Richard Flanagan's "The Narrow Road to the Deep North." Mukherjee's novel is the favorite to win, with Jacobson's "J" next in the betting. The shortlist features three British writers, two Americans, and an Australian, with Fowler's novel being the best-selling. The prize, in its 46th year, will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night, with coverage on BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

The passage describes a legal battle over the publication of alleged extra-marital activities involving a celebrity referred to as PJS. The Sun on Sunday, the publisher of the story, wants to publish the account, while PJS argues for his right to privacy. The case has been through several courts, with the High Court initially refusing to impose an injunction barring publication. However, an appeal court ruled in PJS's favor, preventing his identification in publications in England and Wales. The publisher then appealed to the Court of Appeal, which lifted the ban, citing the widespread nature of the story and the difficulty in maintaining confidentiality. The Supreme Court has now agreed to hear arguments on whether to grant an appeal and decide if the ban should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction remains in place until the hearing concludes.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, was opened in 1989 and recently purchased for £345.5m in August. The new owners, Crown Estates, are planning improvements to parking, traffic congestion, and the aesthetics of the units. The council and new owners have discussed potential planning issues, with the council leader, Ernie White, emphasizing the importance of enhancing the view as one enters the city. Crown Estates' director, Paul Clarke, highlighted the need to address parking and congestion issues and improve the quality of common areas and facilities.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" in the film. The live-action remake, directed by Bill Condon, features a subplot involving LeFou, the sidekick of the main antagonist Gaston, who grapples with feelings for Gaston. The film was initially scheduled for release on Thursday but was delayed for a "review" of its content by Disney. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film but required a minor edit concerning the gay moment. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia, but the country's tourism minister has deemed banning the film "ridiculous." The LPF Chairman, Datuk Abdul Hamid, stated that the board only reviews content and does not control the screening date or location. Local cinema chains have offered refunds to customers who purchased tickets in advance. The decision to review the film has been criticized by netizens, who have called it "stupid and laughable."

To put the passage in a nutshell: Landlords in Southampton who let properties to more than three unrelated people need to apply for a licence for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO), but many are put off by the cost.

The passage discusses the political situation in Ireland following the recent election, where no party was able to form a majority government. Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are working to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil has indicated they will support a minority government but will not endorse a programme for government. One of the main issues preventing agreement is the water charges, with Fianna Fáil advocating for their immediate removal and Fine Gael seeing a role for them. Currently, Fine Gael has 50 seats, Fianna Fáil has 44, Sinn Féin has 23, and the Labour Party has seven seats.

The Sorrento, a ferry owned by an Italian company, caught fire while traveling to Valencia and quickly got out of control. The passengers were evacuated onto lifeboats and rescued by another ship, the Puglia. At least three people were injured, with one reported to be seriously hurt. The fire broke out on one of the car decks, about 27km from Mallorca, and the cause remains unclear. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, assisted in the rescue. The rescued passengers were taken to Palma de Mallorca and were expected to arrive at the port within a few hours. Psychologists were on standby to provide counseling. The Balearic Islands port authority warned that The Sorrento may sink in its current position.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs identified instances of people, including students, claiming to have voted twice, which is a criminal offense. The commission suggested that individual electoral registers run by councils should be better connected to identify duplicate entries. Despite a record number of 46.8 million people registered to vote in the 8 June election, concerns persist over duplicate applications, with an estimated 30% to 70% of applications being duplicates in different areas. The commission recommends clearer information on registration sites and a verification function, similar to those used in Australia, New Zealand, and the Republic of Ireland. The watchdog also called for people registered in two seats to choose in advance which one they will vote in at future general elections. Labour warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote, emphasizing that some people may lawfully register in more than one constituency for local elections.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, was found dead in his cell on Wednesday. He was 40 years old and had a troubled life, both on and off the field. After his NFL career, he faced legal issues, including assault convictions and a long prison sentence. He was placed in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate. Phillips' former coach, Tom Osborne, noted his intelligence and good qualities but also acknowledged his struggles with anger and the inability to overcome life's challenges.

Private Derby XXX, a ram officially classed as a soldier, was promoted to the rank of lance corporal at an event in Chester. The promotion was awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams, the colonel of the Mercian Regiment, for "good behaviour." This is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century. The first Private Derby was acquired in 1858 by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot and became the mascot of the Mercian Regiment when it formed in 2007. Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014 and has his own army number, is paid for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. During his career, he has also helped switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial commemorating the 1914 Christmas Truce.

The passage describes a thrilling football match between Liverpool and Borussia Dortmund, where Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory. The match was marked by high drama, intense emotions, and a significant turnaround in the team's performance. Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp, known for his ability to inspire his team, played a crucial role in the victory. The match began with Dortmund scoring two goals in the first nine minutes, leaving Liverpool in doubt. However, Klopp's leadership and the team's determination led to a remarkable comeback. Liverpool scored three goals in quick succession, with key contributions from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, and Mamadou Sakho, culminating in Dejan Lovren's late goal that secured the victory.

The atmosphere at Anfield was electric, with the supporters playing a vital role in the team's success. Klopp's approach, which emphasizes turning doubters into believers, was evident in the way the team and fans rallied together.
