The match was a testament to the team's resilience and the impact of Klopp's leadership. Despite the victory, the passage also highlights areas for improvement, such as Liverpool's vulnerability at the back and the need for better positional play. However, the overall performance and the team's growing confidence under Klopp's guidance suggest a promising future for Liverpool in the Europa League and potentially a return to the Champions League.

The passage discusses a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, where UK government officials discussed the process of involving Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland in the UK's negotiations with the EU. Mr. Davis, a UK government official, stated that the government would keep the devolved administrations informed and proposed monthly meetings to share information and analysis. Mr. Russell, from the Scottish government, emphasized the need for greater transparency and clarity from the UK government regarding its strategic intentions, particularly on EU market access. He stressed that membership of the single market is essential for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government hopes the High Court's judgment on triggering Article 50 will be overruled by the Supreme Court, but the Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court.

The passage describes a detailed physical examination of Daisy, one of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, by veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr. These sheep are cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal born in 1996. The examination focuses on signs of crepitus, lameness, and other indicators of disease or osteoarthritis, which are crucial for assessing the health and aging process of the cloned sheep. The study, led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, aims to determine if cloned animals age normally and how healthy they are, addressing concerns about "age-memory" being transferred through the cloning process. The original Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old, suffering from osteoarthritis, which raised questions about premature aging. To answer these questions, the researchers have subjected the cloned sheep to a battery of tests, including joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans, focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study, which could have significant implications for the future of cloning, will be published next week.

The passage discusses a horse racing event where the unbeaten 4-7 favorite, Shutter Speed, won a race after her trainer, John Gosden, walked the course. She beat the runner-up, Vintage Folly, by a length and three quarters. Shutter Speed will next race at Chantilly instead of the Oaks at Epsom, where her stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Another horse, Tasleet, won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. Gosden is concerned about the ground conditions for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will decide whether to enter him in the Derby trial based on the course conditions.

The passage discusses the fluctuating value of the British pound (sterling) in the days leading up to the EU referendum. Initially, the pound slipped against the dollar and euro but began to recover before falling again. The "volatility index," a measure of investor uncertainty, reached levels last seen during the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound had only retreated to March levels. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226, down 0.6% against the euro at €1.2605, and weakened by 1% against the Japanese yen to over 151. Investors were spooked by data showing a decline in the chances of a Remain vote, with two weekend polls indicating the Leave camp was ahead and the implied probability of a Remain vote falling to 68.5% from almost 80% a week earlier. Charalambos Pissouros, a senior analyst at IronFX Global, predicted that incoming polls would cause the pound to fluctuate more aggressively. Kamal Ahmed, the BBC economics editor, noted that hedge funds were short-selling sterling, expecting its value to decline further. Joe Rundle, head of trading at ETX Capital, said the markets were on full Brexit alert, with the pound shedding more than 2% in two sessions. The passage also mentions the impact on Asian stock markets, with Japan's Nikkei index closing 3.5% down and Hong Kong's main index sliding 2.5%. The FTSE 100 initially fell 0.3% but ended the day down 1.1% at 6,044.9 points. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argued that the pound had strengthened since March and that a weaker pound would benefit UK exporters, citing a narrowing of the UK trade deficit in April due to a jump in exports.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. Cowley praised the team's efforts against a strong Barrow team, despite conceding early. Barrow extended their unbeaten run to nine games, while The Iron's losing streak reached three games. Cowley remained optimistic, emphasizing the team's remarkable achievements and their determination to embrace the challenge, despite being a part-time team.

The passage discusses a significant change in Northern Ireland's planning system, where local councils will take over the responsibility for most planning decisions from the Planning Service, an agency under Stormont's environment department. This shift, set to begin in April 2015, will allow councils to accept or reject developments in their own areas, with elected politicians making the final decisions. The move is seen as a positive step by Michael Corr, the creative director of PLACE, who believes it offers local councils an opportunity to develop their own community and development plans. However, concerns are raised about the political skills of Northern Ireland's politicians and the potential for discrimination and corruption, similar to issues seen in the 1960s. The environmental group Friends of the Earth emphasizes the need for a strict code of conduct and transparency to ensure fair and transparent planning. The passage also touches on the potential impact on political donations and the security of local politicians.

A concise summary of the passage is: A cat was shot three times with an air gun, and the Scottish SPCA is urging the Scottish government to implement licensing for air guns to prevent further incidents.

The passage discusses the signing of Christian Benteke by Liverpool FC. Benteke, a 24-year-old Belgium international, becomes the club's second most expensive signing after triggering a release clause in his contract. He joins Liverpool on a long-term contract and is their seventh summer signing. Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa, where he was brought in by manager Paul Lambert from Genk for £7m in 2012. Liverpool, who sold Luis Suarez to Barcelona for £75m, struggled for goals last season due to Suarez's departure and injuries to Daniel Sturridge. Manager Brendan Rodgers has added Benteke to bolster the team's attack. Benteke is excited about his move, stating he came to Liverpool to win trophies and reach great goals with the team. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert believes Benteke will do well at Anfield, while former Liverpool striker John Aldridge is optimistic about Benteke's impact, praising his presence, speed, strength, and aggression.

The passage discusses a study commissioned by the education technology charity Tablets for Schools, which examined the use of tablet devices in schools. The study found that while tablets are increasingly being used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using these devices. The study, headed by Barbie Clarke, looked at a representative sample of 671 state and independent schools and found that many pupils use their internet-connected devices to continue social media conversations even after school hours. The study also highlighted that 9% of schools have an individual tablet device for every pupil, with the highest use found in academy schools. Among schools not currently using tablets, 45% reported that they would soon be likely to introduce them. The number of tablet computers in schools is expected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. Dr. Clarke, formerly of the University of Cambridge's education department, notes that while there is no definitive connection between tablet computers and improved academic results, head teachers reported a positive impact, particularly in motivating disengaged pupils and increasing family involvement. A separate study from the National Literacy Trust and Pearson suggested that touch-screen computers are particularly useful for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. The passage also mentions that within schools where every pupil has a tablet, a quarter of secondary pupils described themselves as internet "addicts," and about two-thirds took a computer device or smartphone to bed with them for social media or video use. The study underscores the growing role of technology in schools, with Simon Mason, head of Honywood Community School in Essex, advocating for tablet computers as a way to ensure the school is "in the current century and not the last." Mason argues that tablets create a sense of empowerment for young people and reflect the reality of how pupils live at home and what they will find at work.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 evocative photographs that span over 100 years, from the 1880s to the 1990s, capturing the lives of children in Liverpool. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, provides a social history of life in Liverpool through the decades, illustrating significant changes in children's lives and how special occasions were celebrated on the city's streets. The oldest photograph dates back to 1887 and depicts the Rollo family, who lived in a large home with servants, attending a fancy dress ball. Another image from around 1900 shows a young maid working for a well-to-do family, highlighting the reality of child labor. The exhibition aims to present both happy and challenging aspects of childhood, offering a comprehensive view of the experiences of children in Liverpool over the decades.

The passage discusses two recent football transfers involving Barrow's National League rivals. Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left his contract with Barrow by mutual consent to join their rivals. Anderson, who has played for Aldershot and Exeter, and also had a stint in Italy, might face his former club in a match on 18 February. Meanwhile, striker Keating, 21, has been recommended to Barrow's manager Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams, the former manager of Port Vale. Keating has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, and his transfer is subject to international clearance. Nicholson praises Anderson as a leader and a player of the stature he has been seeking, while describing Keating as young and hungry to prove himself. Barrow is currently four points above the relegation zone and has won only one of their last six games.

The passage discusses a new law in Bolivia that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental consent, reflecting the country's economic needs and poverty. The law also imposes harsher penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. Approved by Congress and signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, the law aims to balance legal rights with the harsh realities of Bolivian life. According to Unicef, over 500,000 children work in Bolivia, often in dangerous conditions. The government hopes the law will help reduce extreme poverty. The International Labour Organisation (ILO) allows a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries but is studying the legislation to ensure it does not breach international child labor regulations.

The passage describes a 50-year-old woman, O'Donnell, who experienced a heart attack after helping a woman out of her car. She initially looked up "women's heart attack symptoms" online, which included nausea and aches, and took aspirin. The next day, she visited a cardiologist who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked. O'Donnell's blog entry, titled "my heart attack," revealed that her type of heart attack was known as the "widow maker." She did not call emergency services but warned her readers to recognize symptoms and call 911.

A concise summary of the passage is: A 16-year-old boy, Che Labastide-Wellington, was stabbed and killed at a party in Kenton, London. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. A 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on suspicion of murder. A 14-year-old boy is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage discusses the introduction of a new diagnostic approach in Denmark to improve cancer survival rates, particularly for cases with vague or difficult-to-diagnose symptoms. The problem was identified through alarming cancer survival statistics from over 15 years ago, showing Denmark performing poorly compared to other European countries. The new model of care in Denmark has three routes: 

1. Fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with specific cancer symptoms, with strict time targets.
2. Diagnosis centers at hospitals and clinics for patients with symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose, providing a range of tests and scans quickly.
3. "Yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms, offering simple tests or scans to quickly identify any problems.

The changes have not led to an overwhelming increase in GP referrals but have improved the organization of diagnosis within existing resources, resulting in better survival rates. Denmark's health system, similar to Wales, can share lessons on better organization to catch up with European elites.

The passage discusses a new initiative by Powys council to take over the responsibilities of the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in issuing warning and banning orders against dishonest or law-breaking estate agents. This move follows the UK government's decision to disband the OFT. Powys won a competitive bid to provide this service and will receive £170,000 annually for it. People who complain about estate agents will continue to contact their local authority trading standards department, which will prosecute offenders if necessary. However, if the local authority believes that parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached, they will refer the cases to Powys. James Munro, from Powys council, who will lead the new team, hopes this role will demonstrate Powys' capability to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The NHS Employers management body has approved a plan to redefine the roles of nurses and other healthcare professionals to help cover for doctor shortages and the increasing number of patients. The Nuffield Trust review found that nurses are already filling in for doctors and pharmacists for GPs in some areas. However, unions warn against using this as a quick fix for NHS problems, emphasizing the need for proper training and funding. The report highlights the changing nature of care, focusing on long-term conditions rather than curing illnesses, and suggests that more responsibilities should be given to other health staff. Despite support for increasing the skills of the workforce, concerns are raised about the quality of training for doctors and the potential financial strain on the health service.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place after a crash at 03:00 GMT, which caused the A36 road to be closed until 14:00 GMT. This closure led to disruption and delays for commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations are ongoing to determine how the collision occurred. First, the bus company, stated that while some services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. Managing director James Freeman expressed hope for a full service by the evening commute and thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts.

The passage discusses a dispute between the Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) regarding the environmental impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project. NRW estimated that the lagoon would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year as they migrate to and from local rivers, based on the "best available evidence." TLP disputed these figures, claiming they lack a "clear scientific basis" and that NRW refused to share its methodology for calculating them. TLP's own computer modeling suggested a "worst case scenario" where the lagoon would kill only 2% of all fish species. The UK government is currently reviewing the project's viability, and Wales' Environment Secretary, Lesley Griffiths, expressed the Welsh Government's support for the scheme but called for clarity on the UK government's position. NRW strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism, emphasizing that its figures are based on extensive evidence and independent expert assessments.

The passage discusses the announcement by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster to establish a new agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland. This body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), is expected to play a significant role in the sector, which employs almost 100,000 people in various fields including farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. The new body is modeled after Scotland Food and Drink and will provide strategic leadership and direction for both government and private sector marketing activities. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the move, emphasizing the need for better coordination of current marketing activities and the potential implications for other organizations, including her own department.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon, inviting the public to participate. This is part of a four-year project to plant "millions" of native UK trees, commemorating the millions who died during WW1. The goal is to plant 40,000 trees in tribute to the 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The project aims to create a place where wildlife thrives and people can walk, relax, and reflect. The charity is providing saplings and advising volunteers to wear welly boots or "stout footwear." Brackfield Wood is located about seven miles outside Derry city, and limited parking is available.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin," which tackles domestic violence and honour crime. Ann Cleeves, the festival programming chair, praised the book for its finely written and tightly plotted narrative. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career writing about the female private investigator VI Warshawski, who was a game changer in crime fiction by being an action hero and a strong female protagonist. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally.

The passage discusses the cricket career of Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner who made his Test debut in 2015. In 2016, Santner broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire, which was a significant setback for the team. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes mentioned that losing Santner was a major blow to Worcestershire's hopes of qualifying, as they had a good start and Santner's consistent play would have been an extra advantage. Santner will return to the team after the ICC Trophy in England in June 2017, expressing his desire to make up for lost time and contribute more effectively with both bat and ball. Additionally, in August 2016, Worcestershire signed John Hastings, an Australian pace bowler, as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats of the game.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed by a speeding car with stolen license plates while trying to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008. The coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, ruled his death a verdict of unlawful killing, citing that his guard was lowered by inebriation and the car did not brake or stop. The case highlights the difficulties in investigating deaths abroad. Pring's wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was 19 years younger than him and was accused of involvement in his death to inherit his wealth. She sold his car, moved funds from his bank account, and was found to have an affair with a Ukrainian man. The Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry but later relaunched it as a murder investigation, which remains active but not actively pursued.

The passage describes the urgent need for experimental T-Cell Therapy for Charlie Fearns, a three-year-old boy from Merseyside, who has been ill since the age of three. The treatment, which is unavailable in the UK, is required at Seattle Children's Hospital in America. Charlie's mother, Sophie Fearns, expressed her "ecstasy" and "overwhelm" at the news that an anonymous donor had paid for the treatment. The family was left "heartbroken" when the first T-Cell transplant did not work, and there were no further treatment options available in the UK. The anonymous donor's generosity has provided financial clearance for Charlie's treatment, which is expected to begin as soon as possible. Charlie's father, Rob Fearns, expressed their "extreme gratitude" for the donation.

The passage discusses the implementation of two-step verification as a security measure by Apple to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud accounts, particularly in response to the recent hacking incidents involving celebrities' intimate photos. This security feature, which requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone or via the Find My iPhone app, was previously optional but is now set to become the default option. The change is designed to enhance security by adding an extra layer of protection after the initial login with a username and password. 

The implementation of this feature is seen as a response to the use of Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, a tool that hackers have used to access iCloud data without needing the physical device. The owner of Elcomsoft has acknowledged that Apple's new security measures effectively counter the technique used in the recent hacks. Additionally, Apple now notifies account owners via email when a backup starts downloading, regardless of whether two-factor authentication is enabled.

However, concerns have been raised about the complexity of remembering the 14-character recovery key and the potential risks if it is lost or stolen. Some experts, like Prof Alan Woodward from the University of Surrey, advocate for making two-factor authentication the default setting across all major tech companies, including Apple, Microsoft, and Google, to enhance overall security. Apple has indicated plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and to use stronger passwords.

The passage discusses a potential deal where Wright, a 30-year-old former I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here contestant, could buy 20% of Billericay Football Club. The core details include Wright potentially becoming a club director, Billericay's current standing in the Isthmian League Premier Division, and recent developments such as the club's takeover by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin and the signing of former England international Paul Konchesky.

The passage discusses a request for Mr. Ashley to provide evidence regarding the treatment of workers at his Derbyshire company, Sports Direct, following a BBC investigation. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, has written to Mr. Ashley, giving him until 21 March to respond. Mr. Wright's letter states that the committee will be reviewing the treatment of low-paid workers and the enforcement of the national minimum wage. The BIS committee has offered several alternative dates for Mr. Ashley to attend a public meeting at Westminster, but he has not accepted any of them. If Mr. Ashley fails to respond, the committee may take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons for any complaint of contempt. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for a comment.

The passage discusses a report, "Putin. War," which was initiated by Boris Nemtsov and later completed by his colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin, following Nemtsov's assassination. The report, written in Russian, compiles facts about the conflict in eastern Ukraine since the annexation of Crimea in 2014, aiming to present a compelling case that President Vladimir Putin is responsible for waging war in Ukraine for his own benefit. The authors argue that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial in securing major victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk, with soldiers admitting to being directed by Russian generals. The report also documents the economic cost of the conflict, estimated at 53 billion roubles, and the high salaries paid to volunteer soldiers. Despite the availability of this information online and in some liberal media, the report faces challenges in publication and distribution due to fear and resistance from publishers. The opposition views Putin's involvement as an attempt to boost his popularity, a strategy that has been successful, but the report may face the same fate as earlier works by Nemtsov, which did not galvanize widespread protest.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. The cause of death was determined to be head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the tensions between the UK government and the Welsh government regarding the Article 50 letter. Carwyn Jones, the first minister of Wales, complains that he was not consulted or informed about the letter before its publication, a sentiment shared by many in Mrs. May's cabinet. Jones argues that the lack of consultation is unacceptable and part of a broader pattern of disrespect towards devolved administrations. Despite this, Mrs. May did mention Wales in the letter, stating that the UK government will consult on which powers should remain in Westminster and which should be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, with an expectation of increased decision-making power for each devolved administration. However, the specifics of which powers and whether the financial support will follow remain unclear. The passage also touches on the political implications of the EU funding in Wales and the potential for a white paper to provide more details on the process.

In the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night, two cars were damaged in an incident. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his disgust at the attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were performing their duties when attacked and also urged parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

The passage describes the ousting of Mr. Charney, the founder and former CEO of a company, due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The board of directors filed a court document stating they do not expect him to return to the firm. Mr. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, accused the company of invading his privacy and attempting to extort him. The court filing includes evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts by Mr. Charney to female employees. In response to Mr. Charney's defamation lawsuit, the company's documents claim he violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The board argues that no company would hire him due to the risks he poses to the company and its shareholders. Additionally, Mr. Charney was granted a restraining order preventing him from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses a basketball match between Greece and Great Britain (GB). The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. In their previous encounter, Greece won 92-64 in Patras, Greece. Three players from that Greek team will not be playing in the Copper Box, giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, who is from Stratford, is excited about playing at the Copper Box and believes the atmosphere will be great. The game is part of GB's preparation for EuroBasket 2017, which begins in September. After the match, GB will play in a four-team tournament in Poland before heading to EuroBasket. The game is scheduled to start at 17:30 BST and will be broadcast from 17:30 to 19:30 on both BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website.

The passage describes the early days of the iPhone's launch and its impact on technology and society. The author recounts being offered an interview with Apple's marketing chief, Phil Schiller, and being given the opportunity to hold the iPhone for a news segment. The author compares the initial skepticism and criticism of the iPhone's prominence in media coverage to its eventual revolutionary impact on technology. The iPhone's introduction marked the beginning of the smartphone era, transforming how people communicate, access information, and take photos. The author reflects on how the iPhone's user-friendly interface, designed by Steve Jobs, made it accessible and appealing to a broad audience, leading to widespread adoption and the disruption of various industries. The passage concludes by noting that while other companies like Amazon and Google continue to innovate with AI-driven products, the iPhone's launch in San Francisco in January 2007 marked the start of the mobile connected era.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, tests confirmed that multiple cats, including a seven-month-old named Meereen, had ingested a toxic substance, with the most recent case resulting in Meereen's death. The cause of death was confirmed to be antifreeze. The RSPCA is unsure whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. Three other cats in the area have died in the last week, and another died two weeks ago. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, described her as "devastated" after finding her foaming from the mouth and trying to be sick. An RSPCA inspector is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially during the time of year when antifreeze is commonly used in cars.

The passage discusses the current state of Greece under the Syriza government, which is set to implement more austerity measures despite its previous stance against them. Despite the economic hardships, including VAT increases, pension cuts, and reductions in farm subsidies, there are no major protests on the streets of Athens. The passage suggests that this may be due to the anticipation of a new bailout deal, which could reveal how much Tsipras has conceded to secure €86 billion from the eurozone and possibly the IMF. The deal could potentially bring an end to the economic crisis and improve the situation for Greek citizens. However, the passage also highlights the economic challenges, such as the partial closure of banks and the lack of credit for businesses, which could further impoverish the Greek people. The success of the new bailout deal will depend on whether it offers a genuine path to recovery and whether creditors show debt forgiveness.

The passage discusses Ross Kemp's return to the BBC soap opera "EastEnders" to reprise his role as Grant Mitchell. Kemp, who last played the character in 2006, will make a brief appearance for the final episodes of Barbara Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, who is set to die from cancer. Grant's return is significant as it reunites the Mitchell family for the last time. The storyline involves Grant telling his eldest son Phil, played by Steve McFadden, that his cancer has returned. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins praises the opportunity for Kemp and McFadden to showcase their acting skills in these emotional scenes.

The passage describes the tragic murder of Alice Ruggles by Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon in October. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, recount the moment they learned of her death and the subsequent trial at Newcastle Crown Court. Dr. Hills expressed her guilt over reassuring Alice on the phone two days before the attack, believing her daughter's concerns were unfounded. The trial revealed Dhillon's obsession with Alice and his stalking behavior. Alice's parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking, using their daughter's "vibrant personality" to remember her as a smiling and laughing individual. Dhillon, 26, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The passage discusses the Hinkley Point project, a £18bn nuclear power plant in Somerset, financed primarily by French firm EDF. The project was approved by EDF's board, with contracts set to be signed on Friday. However, the UK government, under Business Secretary Greg Clark, has announced a "careful consideration" before backing the project, leading to EDF chief executive Vincent de Rivaz cancelling a trip to Hinkley Point. Critics of the plan highlight environmental concerns, potential cost escalations, and the involvement of foreign governments, particularly China, which is providing one third of the £18bn cost. The government launched a further review of the project hours after EDF's board approval, causing confusion and concern among EDF executives and stakeholders. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement and is seen as beneficial for both French and British industries, though it has faced financial and environmental scrutiny. The passage also mentions the project's environmental impact, including the movement of 5.6m cubic metres of earth and the use of 4,000km of electrical cabling and 230,000 tonnes of steel. The government's decision is seen as a high-stakes move, potentially signaling a change in policy or a genuine pause for review.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales now asks for the name of the person the spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers argue that this addition increases conflict and complexity, as naming a third party is not necessary and can make the legal process more contentious. The Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to provide this information, but the form's guidance suggests it is "not normally necessary." However, the new form explicitly asks for the name, which many believe will lead to more people naming the third party. If named, they become part of the court case, receive copies of the paperwork, and can respond, potentially delaying proceedings and incurring more costs. In 2015, adultery was the reason for 12,148 divorces out of over 100,000 granted in England and Wales.

The passage discusses the conflict between environmental policy and commercial forestry in Wales. Britain is the world's third largest importer of wood, and the Welsh government is encouraging commercial forestry organizations to invest in woodland creation. Conifer forests, which have been a familiar sight in Wales for half a century, have contributed to the growth of the timber industry. However, Confor, an organization promoting the forestry industry, warns that at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be re-planted to meet demand. The forestry industry is estimated to be worth more than £450m a year to the Welsh economy. The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development, as seen in their Glastir scheme and Woodlands for Wales forestry strategy. However, there is a conflict with environmental policy, as conservationists claim commercial forests are harmful to wildlife. Martin Bishop of Confor believes the emphasis on environmental aspects is seen as more appealing than commercial forestry and that the current system is too bureaucratic for creating new woodland areas.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street. Emergency crews responded and transported him to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is reported to be serious.

The passage describes a ceremony where Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys. The Foreign Office initially blocked the Russian honouring of the veterans due to rules against foreign medals, but an exception was made, and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London in 2013. The Arctic Convoys were a series of maritime missions during World War II, where British vessels travelled to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union. These convoys faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, severe cold, storms, and ice floes. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. The Russian Embassy recognized the veterans for their role in providing weapons and ammunition that helped defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front.

The passage discusses the findings of the HM Inspectorate of Probation regarding delays and inefficiencies in the enforcement of unpaid work, or "community payback," for offenders. The report highlights that many offenders are not starting their sentences on time, and those who miss work are often let off without consequences. One offender, for example, completed only 16 hours of work in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the issues and is working on implementing the report's recommendations. The report, based on 100 cases and interviews with 86 offenders, outlines 15 recommendations for improvement. The government's past efforts to rebrand and intensify community payback have not fully addressed the organizational challenges, such as the difficulty in managing offenders with chaotic lifestyles and substance abuse issues. The report praises instances of high-quality work and positive attitudes among offenders but criticizes the lack of focus on delivering and enforcing court sentences. The chief inspector, Paul Wilson, calls for urgent action to improve the system, emphasizing that unpaid work should be seen as a rehabilitation opportunity rather than just a punishment. The Ministry of Justice has accepted the recommendations and is taking steps to implement them.

The passage discusses the criticism faced by comedian Ricky Gervais, who is accused of being a "hypocrite" for advocating for economic and political "revolution" to help the poor while living in a luxury home in London. The paper, The Sun, ran a front-page headline calling him a hypocrite. Gervais, known for his vlogs "The Trews," has been vocal about his support for the poor and his belief in change. He has been asked about his living situation by a TV reporter, which led to a confrontation with a Channel 4 News journalist who asked about his rent. Gervais called the journalist "a snide" and walked off. Despite the criticism, Gervais has not taken legal action against The Sun but has been tweeting about the accusations using the hashtag #TheSunLogic. He has defended himself by acknowledging his past mistakes and his belief in personal and systemic change. He argues that the system that has made him wealthy and famous is part of the problem and that addressing inequality is a real issue that needs to be addressed.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the human genome mapping effort into a competitive race, which earned him criticism from the scientific community. Despite his wealth and ambition, his contributions significantly accelerated the process. After the human genome was mapped, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, leading to the development of Synthia, a synthetic organism detailed in the journal Science. Born in 1946, Venter's early life and experiences in Vietnam shaped his determination to excel in research and his sense of urgency. He revolutionized gene sequencing by focusing on messenger RNA instead of the entire DNA blueprint, achieving unprecedented rates. His work on Haemophilus influenzae and the human genome, completed in three years by Celera Genomics, further challenged scientific conventions. Venter's private funding and resources allowed him to pursue his scientific goals without bureaucratic constraints. His current project, the J Craig Venter Institute, aims to create the world's first synthetic life form and explore the genetic diversity of marine microbes.

The passage discusses a survey conducted by England's School Food Trust, which found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents surveyed said their children had asked for school foods to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were the least popular. The survey, which included about 1,000 parents, was commissioned after a Mumsnet survey suggested that some parents gave their children packed lunches because they were too fussy to eat school food. The School Food Trust's chairman, Rob Rees, noted that school meals can help parents encourage their children to try new foods and increase dietary variety. Mumsnet co-founder, Carrie Longton, added that school meals have become healthier and more varied, and that children are more likely to try new foods at school due to peer pressure and a desire to fit in. School meals in England now have to comply with strict nutritional guidelines, and about four in 10 primary school children in England now eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools.

The passage discusses the career of Spanish footballer Morata, who is 23 years old and currently playing for Spain at Euro 2016. Morata joined Italian club Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. The transfer terms included an option for Real to buy him back, with the reported fee being up to 30 million euros (£23 million). Morata was previously targeted by Arsenal and Chelsea. For Juventus, he scored 27 goals in two years, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. Morata has also played in back-to-back Champions League finals, appearing as a substitute in Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 2015 defeat by Barcelona. He began his career at Real, making his first team debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

The passage discusses the career of a football player named Wilson. He returned to Championship side Forest from Celtic in August 2013 for a fee of £2.5m. During his second stint at Forest, he made 51 appearances. Before joining Celtic, Wilson spent four seasons at Forest. Additionally, Wilson has played for Preston North End and Notts County. As of the time of the passage, Wilson has been without a team since being released in May.

The passage discusses Tesco's decision to exit the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy supermarket chain to a private equity company, Yucaipa. Approximately 4,000 out of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, and Tesco will provide a loan of around £80m. Fresh & Easy, which operates 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been unprofitable since its inception in 2007. Tesco will close the remaining 50 stores and incur a £150m cost to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand, part of which is the loan that may be repaid. If Yucaipa is successful and the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. Yucaipa is a Los Angeles-based private equity company run by billionaire investor Ron Burkle.

The passage discusses an individual who initially faced racial abuse but overcame this challenge. After briefly considering representing France, the person is now focused on achieving a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Additionally, the passage suggests reading a special guide for those interested in getting into martial arts.

The passage discusses the significant retreat of ice fields in the French Alps, particularly around Mont Blanc and the surrounding mountain ranges. In the late 1960s/early 1970s, these ice fields covered about 375 square kilometers. By the late 2000s, this area had decreased to approximately 275 square kilometers, representing an average loss of about 26% over the last 40 years. The research, presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting, was conducted by Marie Gardent and her colleagues from the University of Savoie. They assessed roughly 600 glaciers in the Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, and Grande Rousse Arves massifs, as well as the Mont Blanc Massif. The team used map archives, past satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual inspection to verify the accuracy of the automatic delineation methods due to issues with debris cover and deep shadows. The retreat is not uniform across the French Alps; the greatest losses have been observed in the southern sectors, where glaciers have almost completely disappeared in the Belledonne Massif and glacial retreat is more than three times stronger in the Ecrins Massif compared to the Mont Blanc Massif. The northern region, including the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has experienced less significant retreat due to lower elevations and different climatic conditions, with more precipitation and cloud cover.

The Scots women's soccer team has won all five qualifiers to date and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, aiming to secure their place in the major competitions. The Scots are desperate to avoid another play-off loss, having come close in previous years. Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland at number 20 in the world, is also unbeaten after four wins from four. The outcome of Friday's match and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September will likely decide who tops the group. The Scots are in pole position to reach the finals in the Netherlands without a play-off, with the best six of the eight group runners-up qualifying automatically. The Scots have 12 players in the 20-strong squad who play outside Scotland, including five at English clubs, four in Sweden, and two at Seattle Reign in the United States National Women's Soccer League.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish blogger and former computer games reviewer, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint of online harassment from a woman in south London. The alleged harassment took place over a two-year period and involved tweets from his Twitter account, which he maintains were not threatening. Campbell was released on bail and has been accused by the media of "innuendo" designed to encourage "speculations." He has been a vocal campaigner for Scottish independence and has been bailed until mid-September for further inquiries.

The passage discusses a proposal by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) to replace the mascot of Skegness, the Jolly Fisherman, with a modern, animal-friendly alternative. Peta suggests a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, welcomes suggestions but doubts there will be much support for replacing the Jolly Fisherman. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway, has become synonymous with Skegness and features the slogan "Skegness is so bracing." Peta argues that the Jolly Fisherman evokes images of animal cruelty, such as fish being tricked into impaling themselves and animals being crushed in nets. The mayor, however, sees the Jolly Fisherman as a beloved, happy, and friendly symbol for the resort. The suggestion will be considered by the council, but the mayor believes the current mascot is not broken and should not be changed.

The passage describes a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia, where Scotland emerged victorious. The match saw Scotland scoring multiple tries and maintaining a significant lead throughout. Key moments include:

- Scotland's early lead with Vasil Lobzhanidze's try, followed by Tommy Seymour's try, a penalty try, and Sean Maitland's and Stuart Hogg's tries before halftime.
- Hamish Watson extending the lead after halftime, and Lobzhanidze scoring a second try from a Georgian scrum.
- Hogg's counter-attack try, which was a highlight of the match, and Laidlaw's successful conversions.
- Scotland maintaining possession and territory, with Laidlaw adding more points through conversions and penalties.
- Georgia scoring a penalty to reduce the deficit but failing to capitalize further.
- Scotland's continued dominance, with Maitland scoring another try and Laidlaw adding more points.
- Georgia's scrum causing issues for Scotland, leading to a yellow card for Moray Low.
- Scotland's final try, scored by Hogg, and a strong finish with Ali Price and Rory Hughes contributing.

The match highlighted Scotland's strong performance, effective ball management, and counter-attacking strategies, while Georgia struggled to maintain possession and territory. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised the team's improvement and their ability to manage the game effectively.

The passage describes a rugby league match where Widnes defeated Castleford. Key points include:

- Widnes scored 14 points in the first half, with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, giving them a 14-6 half-time lead.
- Paddy Flynn, a loanee from Castleford, scored against his parent club, but Widnes extended their lead with tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor, making it 38-12.
- Despite Castleford scoring three tries in four minutes, Widnes held on, with Mellor's try giving them a 26-point lead.
- Castleford's defense weakened, allowing Larne Patrick, who had just signed a three-year deal with Castleford, to score a try. Luke Gale and Flynn's hat-trick made the final score 38-24.
- This victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth place, one point above the Vikings.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old man, was released from the US facility in Cuba after a US review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat." He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. He had challenged America's right to detain him in the US Supreme Court. Mr. Odah boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and will spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. The release came after the Guantanamo Periodic Review Board determined that continued law of war detention of Mr. Odah was not necessary to protect against a continuing significant threat to the security of the United States. Mr. Odah's release brings the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148.

Anzac Day is commemorated in London with a significant number of attendees at Hyde Park Corner and a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. The service at Westminster Abbey is also notable, with the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia being sung. The first Anzac Day service in London was in 1916, following the Gallipoli landings. The event is a moment of reflection and honor for the sacrifices made by Australian and New Zealand forces in all wars. Alexander Downer, the Australian high commissioner to the UK, addressed the crowds, emphasizing the courage and heroism of the Anzac troops. The ceremony included prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK.

Clarkson, 30, rejoined Premiership Well for a second stint in July and is set to make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has primarily played as a substitute this term. Clarkson is confident and fit, having trained hard to ensure he is ready for his debut. He has been capped twice for Scotland and has made nearly 400 senior appearances at club level. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of Alloa. Clarkson is optimistic about the team's prospects and hopes to help the club regain its previous success.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. Concerns about the new owners not taking on the existing workers' pension scheme were alleviated as Unite, the union representing the workers, was given guarantees that all current agreements would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme, which was closed in 2004, is unaffected by the takeover, as members have an alternative pension scheme. Boparan Private Office confirmed that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. Unite's regional officer, Steve Harley, met with Boparan representatives and was assured that the new owner plans to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitable state through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing the company's spare capacity for chicken processing.

The new ferry has faced numerous issues since its launch, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training problems. To address these issues, the council has decided to offer free crossings until 2 July to allow feedback and recognize the problems. The council has also ordered a review of the project by auditors. Local businesses, particularly those in East Cowes, have been significantly affected by the ferry's issues, with some shopkeepers expressing concerns about their survival. The council is considering compensation for local businesses and has taken steps to resolve specific problems, such as authorizing the manufacture of ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage and addressing seamanship issues.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights that fishing regions around the UK voted strongly for leaving the EU, and the Lords review warns that these communities could be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been criticized by the industry, leading to a desire for control over UK waters post-Brexit. However, the Lords report notes that UK fishing contributes minimally to GDP and employs few people, suggesting it might be a low priority for the government. The report also points out that many commercial fish stocks are shared with other EU coastal states, and the UK's fish exports are primarily to the EU, while much of the fish consumed in the UK is imported from EU states. The report suggests that continued market access to the EU may require the UK to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters. The Lords recommend retaining elements of the CFP, such as scientifically based catch limits, and ensuring cooperation with neighboring states. They also warn that leaving the EU could lead to four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these challenges, the fishing industry remains optimistic about Brexit, seeing it as an opportunity for better management and control over UK waters.

Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old teacher, admitted to downloading and permitting the downloading of child pornography images between April 2004 and February 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order and placed on the sex offenders register. Geaney was removed from the General Teaching Council Scotland register following a hearing that found his conduct "fundamentally incompatible" with being a registered teacher. The panel concluded that his behavior demonstrated a pattern over a long period and had a high likelihood of recurrence, leading to his removal from the teaching profession and a prohibition from re-registering for two years.

The fire at the Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited site in Duncan Street, which occurred on 2 March, lasted several days and disrupted train services and caused travel delays. Following the incident, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste, citing concerns over environmental and safety impacts. The company, run by Asset and Land Group, was found to be "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws by the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS). The EA has decided to revoke the environmental permit for the site, effective 7 August, pending any appeal. The company must remove all waste from the site by this date. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The passage discusses Syria's efforts to comply with the international deadline to destroy its chemical weapons. Despite missing the initial deadline, Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that the country is committed to the process, citing security concerns and attacks on shipments as obstacles. He criticized the US for supporting terrorist elements and condemned the use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where at least 246 people, including 73 children, have been killed in the last five days. The Syrian government denied reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, but the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and other sources claim that rebels have taken control of the prison, which holds at least 3,000 detainees. The passage also highlights the slow progress of the chemical weapons destruction process, with only 4% of the stockpile removed so far.

The passage describes England's victory over Pakistan in the second Test match at Old Trafford, which allowed England to level the four-match series. England scored 589-8 declared in their first innings and 173-1 declared in their second innings, securing a significant win. Joe Root, who was promoted to number three in the series, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket. England's captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, calling it "as good an innings as I've seen." Pakistan's batting performance was poor, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests. The series is expected to be tight, with England in a strong position to win.

The passage discusses the initiative of the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, who is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. Rochira aims to gather experiences from pensioners and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. She plans to highlight both good care practices and the negative impacts of poor care. The review will consider factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing from older people and their families to ensure that those responsible for care services understand the realities of residential care and the necessary changes to improve quality of life. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, supports the review's aims but expresses disappointment that the main advisory panel does not include a care provider expert.

The passage discusses the appointment of former Dons midfielder Paul Sheerin as the new player-manager of Arbroath, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin, who has been with the Red Lichties since 2010, was chosen by Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser after a thorough selection process. Arbroath, which was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing last in League One for the 2013-14 season, was pleased with the decision, as evidenced by the positive comments from Arbroath chairman John Christison. Sheerin, a 39-year-old with a career spanning several Scottish clubs and a stint in Sweden with Östersunds, has also had coaching experience and won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. Notably, he led Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Swansea City Football Club is currently without a manager after Bob Bradley was sacked. Assistant manager Curtis and Paul Williams will take charge of Saturday's match against Bournemouth. The club is keen to appoint a new manager as soon as possible, with former Derby manager Paul Clement being the first choice. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, has a history of being a well-run club with exciting, possession-based football. However, they have struggled since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, and the club is concerned about the possibility of relegation. Curtis, a former player who has been with the club throughout its rise, believes the current squad is good enough to stay up and emphasizes the importance of staying in the Premier League for the club and the local area.

The passage describes the life and achievements of Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who played a significant role in the human genome project and the creation of a synthetic life form. Venter turned the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race, which earned him criticism from the scientific community. Despite this, his methods and achievements have accelerated the process of decoding the human genome. He is known for his wealth and his use of luxury items like Lear Jets and private yachts.

Venter's journey began with a lack of academic focus as a young boy, but his experiences in the Vietnam War, particularly his role as an orderly in a naval field hospital, inspired him to pursue a career in medicine and to value time. During his medical training, he excelled in research and recognized the importance of decoding genes. In the 1980s, he was one of the first to use automated decoding machines, which significantly sped up the process. His breakthrough came when he focused on messenger molecules (RNA) instead of the entire DNA blueprint, allowing him to sequence genes at unprecedented rates.

Venter's work on the human genome project was controversial, with some scientists, including James Watson, dismissing his results as trivial. This led him to leave the NIH in 1992 and establish The Institute for Genomic Research. In 1995, he unveiled the first complete genome of a free-living organism, Haemophilus influenzae. His most ambitious project came in 1998 when he announced the formation of Celera Genomics to decode the entire human genome in just three years, a goal he achieved in 2001.

Venter's work on synthetic life forms began in 2006 with the formation of the J Craig Venter Institute. The institute published details of a synthetic organism called Synthia in the journal Science. Venter's approach to synthetic biology has been met with controversy, but he believes it could lead to a new industrial revolution, potentially helping to reduce oil dependency and mitigate environmental damage by capturing carbon dioxide.

In addition to his scientific achievements, Venter has also been involved in a genetic treasure hunt using his yacht, Sorcerer II, to collect and sequence microbes from the ocean, aiming to enhance understanding of gene evolution and function.

The passage highlights several key points regarding the quality and quantity of apprenticeships in England compared to other European countries, particularly Germany. The Sutton Trust, a UK-based educational charity, warns that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short, and calls for a significant expansion to boost the economy and improve job prospects for young people. The Department for Education is reforming apprenticeships to "drive up standards," while the Association of Colleges suggests that some existing apprenticeships are respected by industry and should be preserved.

The Boston Consulting Group's report, commissioned by the Sutton Trust, reveals that fewer than 200,000 out of 520,000 apprenticeships starting in England each year are rated at level three, equivalent to A-levels. Only 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to over 51% in Germany, which is noted for its robust vocational education system. In Germany, 570,000 new apprenticeships are for young people, with 90% equivalent to A-levels, compared to only 61,000 in England. England's vocational system has 18,000 different qualifications, while Germany has 330.

The report also points out that since 2010, over half of apprenticeships have been below level three, and three-quarters have been aimed at those over 25, many of whom are already in work. The competition for apprenticeships among young people is high, with 11 young people competing for each apprenticeship. Sir Peter Lampl, chairman of the Sutton Trust, emphasizes that the opportunities for young people who do not go to university are poor and calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, primarily at level three or higher. The report advocates for a clearer and more respected vocational system, similar to that in Germany and Switzerland, and suggests that careers advice and guidance need improvement.

The Department for Education is already reforming apprenticeships to make them more rigorous and responsive to employer needs, and has insisted that apprenticeships last at least a year, include more English and maths, and be considered a job. The report calls for a more structured and high-quality vocational education system to enhance economic competitiveness and provide better skilled jobs for young people.

The passage describes a British athlete, Sarah Storey, who won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of her Polish opponent. This victory allows her to potentially secure her 17th title in a road race on Saturday. Storey, a 37-year-old, is aiming for further success in the Paralympics, specifically in Rio de Janeiro next year. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze, across six Paralympics in both cycling and swimming. She has won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has accumulated 21 world titles in total across both sports. Storey began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before transitioning to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United, also known as the Bulls, have been expelled from the Conference Premier due to their financial struggles. The club's debt to football creditors, including former boss Martin Foyle, current squad members, club staff, and other clubs, totaled £148,000. Despite multiple extensions to the payment deadline, Hereford failed to meet the final deadline on June 12. The last team to be expelled from the Conference was Chester City in February 2010, who reformed as Chester FC two months later. Chester FC has taken Hereford's place in the Conference Premier. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust offered to buy the club for £1 and clear their debts, but it was not the preferred option. The club's financial decline has been exacerbated by falling attendances, with the average gate at Edgar Street dropping from 3,270 in League Two to 1,758 in the 2013-14 season.

The passage discusses the career of a former Manchester City player who is 30 years old and has won 61 caps for the England national team since making his senior debut in 2009. He was a part of the squads for two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes at the Euro 2016. The player, who holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, made his first appearance in 2004. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. The passage concludes with the player's statement about the decision reached, wishing success to Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He is remembered for his work with leading orchestras worldwide and his founding of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, which he directed for over three decades. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood's notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, which was ranked among the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. He studied at Cambridge University and held significant positions at the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, the Early Music Consort of London, and various festivals and universities. Hogwood was known for his generosity, intelligence, and his significant impact on the historically informed music movement. His passing is mourned by colleagues and admirers worldwide.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose family wishes to protect his identity, is currently not attending school. His mother had to quit her job to care for him. In June, his parents decided to remove him from mainstream schooling due to his struggles and requested a place at a special school, but they are still waiting. In September, all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full, with no time frame given for availability. The family is now hopeful that their son will be able to attend a local special school with an additional classroom assistant, but the mother is concerned that this situation may affect other families as the special needs school system is over-subscribed. The Education Authority is reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland and is working to ensure that places are available close to where children reside, with the aim to assist with the placement of children from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over the Newport Gwent Dragons, with the intention of using Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. The Newport County Football Club has a lease to use the ground until 2023 and has primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League. The WRU's takeover will be voted on by shareholders on 9 May. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points clear of the relegation zone in League Two and can secure survival this weekend.

The passage describes the personal journey of a survivor who lived through the Sierra Leone civil war and the subsequent Ebola crisis. The individual was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels at 15, where he was trained to use a gun, initiated into the group, and subjected to extreme violence and brutality. He was marked with the letters "RUF" on his chest and faced threats of mutilation or death if he attempted to escape. Despite these horrors, he managed to escape and later found himself involved in petty crime until he met Richard Cole, the founder of Lifeline Nehemiah, who encouraged him to rebuild his life and contribute to society.

The passage then shifts to the Ebola crisis in 2014, where the individual and his peers saw the virus as a common enemy. They transformed their clinic into an Ebola treatment center, educating the public about the virus, providing food and other support, and collaborating with other agencies to set up an Ebola treatment unit. Their efforts saved many lives, and they continued to work tirelessly despite the fear and resistance from the community.

The passage concludes with the individual reflecting on his life, expressing regret for his past actions but confidence in the future. He emphasizes the importance of investing in young people to build a better future, both in Sierra Leone and globally.

The Wedgwood Museum faced the risk of auctioning 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs to pay off the pension debt of the pottery firm. However, a public fundraising campaign led by the Art Fund successfully reached its target in just one month. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The outcome was described as "incredibly satisfying" by administrator Bob Young, who credited the spirit of goodwill and determination during the negotiations. The collection is significant for Staffordshire and plays a crucial role in defining Britain's cultural identity.

The passage discusses a potential deal where Wright, a 30-year-old former I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here contestant, could buy 20% of Billericay FC. If the deal goes through, Wright will also become a club director. Billericay is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, just three points behind a play-off position. Wright has a background in non-league football, having played for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has committed to investing £10,000 a week. Billericay has also signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

The passage describes a soccer match between Blackpool and Colchester United that ended in a 1-1 draw. The first goal was scored by Jamille Matt of Blackpool after 12 minutes, following a pinpoint chip by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester United equalized from a corner kick, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring from close range after a goalmouth scramble. Blackpool had several chances to win the game, including a brilliant save by Sam Slocombe and a missed header by Tom Aldred. Colchester United finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was shown a straight red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The Fawley power station chimney, which closed in 2013, will be repurposed as the tallest disused chimney attraction south of London's Shard. Developers Fawley Waterside plan to transform the site into a £1 billion "merchant city" development, featuring a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The chimney, standing at 198 meters, will serve as the centerpiece of the project. With an outline planning permission application expected later this year, construction could begin in 2018. The 300-acre site, originally an oil-fired power station commissioned in 1971, was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016.

The passage details the performance of British cyclists at the Hong Kong championships. 23-year-old rider, Ethan Latham, secured a bronze medal in the men's scratch race, chasing down gold medalist Adrian Teklinski of Poland and silver medalist Lucass Liss of Germany. Latham expressed his happiness at securing the medal and praised his lead-out rider, Felix English. In the men's team pursuit, GB finished in fourth place, missing out on the bronze medal to Italy. Joe Truman, Britain's sole rider in the men's keirin, was eliminated in his semi-final. The women's team pursuit team, led by Olympic gold medalist Elinor Barker, finished fifth in the heats and did not secure a bronze medal. Barker was positive about the young team's progress and their potential for future success. Olympic bronze medalist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint, expressing disappointment but focusing on her preparation for the upcoming Tokyo Olympics.

The passage discusses Ross Kemp's return to the BBC soap opera "EastEnders" to reprise his role as Grant Mitchell. Kemp, who last played the character in 2006, will make a brief return for the final episodes of Barbara Mitchell's storyline. Barbara, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, returns to Albert Square to inform her eldest son Phil, played by Steve McFadden, that her cancer has returned. Producers have confirmed that Barbara will die from the disease in upcoming emotional scenes. Kemp, who portrayed Grant from 1990 to 1999 and again in 2005 and 2006, is excited about the opportunity to reunite the Mitchell family for the last time. The return of Grant Mitchell is significant as he is one of the soap's most memorable characters, known for his involvement in family dramas and relationships. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins praises the opportunity to showcase Kemp and McFadden at their best as they face the challenge of losing their mother.

The passage discusses a disappointing performance by Tottenham Hotspur (Spurs) in a match against Liverpool at Anfield. Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds, highlighting a lack of desire to win. Pochettino, the manager, expressed concern about Spurs' ability to compete for the Premier League if they continue to show a lack of desire. Chelsea can extend their lead at the top if they win against Burnley on Sunday. Tottenham has struggled on the road, with only two wins since September 24, including defeats at Chelsea and Manchester United, and draws at Arsenal and Manchester City. In their past 17 meetings with top-six sides away from home, they have won only once. Danny Murphy, a former Spurs midfielder, criticized the team's defensive performance and suggested they should stick with their usual back three formation against big sides.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP lost the presidential poll last month for the first time. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May, after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's decline was reinforced by results from Saturday's elections for governors and state assemblies, with the party losing key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as control of Adamawa, one of the states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC has made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. The PDP failed to get a national spread of votes, doing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. Most states in the north went to the APC, along with Nigeria's commercial hub, Lagos, in the south-west. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which will be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were marred by violence in some areas due to ethnic differences and rivalry, but overall, they were more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes that Nigeria's democracy is maturing.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will feature an augmented reality app that allows visitors to trigger online information from signs, posters, and other items on the site. The app will provide videos, band interviews, and other content that can be viewed on phones and tablets. This new feature, added by the festival director Caroline Maclennan, enhances the festival experience and allows people worldwide to interact with the event and capture its atmosphere at any time.

The passage discusses the termination of funding agreements for several Birmingham academies, including Park View and Nansen Primary, which have been rated inadequate by Ofsted.
