Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running these schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools described a culture of fear and intimidation, with parents trying to undermine her authority during an Ofsted inspection. The watchdog published 21 reports into schools allegedly targeted for a hardline Muslim takeover, with five schools, including Park View and Oldknow, rated inadequate. Birmingham City Council will work with Saltley School, the only local authority school placed in special measures, to install a temporary governing board. Education minister Lord Nash expressed deep concerns about the way Park View School was run and criticized the trust for failing to promote spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development. The trust was invited to respond by 4 July. Park View School plans to challenge the Ofsted report through legal channels.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 after a build-up of fluid in his brain increased pressure in his skull, leading to his death. The prosecution alleges that eye specialist Honey Rose failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich and did not refer him for further investigation. The prosecution claims that Rose's negligence was so severe that it constituted criminal conduct. Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse with a man he found through an adult website between September 2013 and September 2014. He was also convicted of sending a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day 2014 and behaving threateningly or abusively towards her family. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and will be sentenced in the High Court in Edinburgh due to its greater sentencing powers.

In the first T20I, Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson hitting 56, Gary Wilson scoring 41 not out, and captain William Porterfield contributing 39. Afghanistan reached 171-4 with Samiullah Shenwari scoring 56 and Mohammad Shahzad 47. Ireland lost early with Paul Stirling dismissed for a duck, but Thompson and Porterfield helped steady the innings. Afghanistan's Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai put on 51. Ireland's loss of Boyd Rankin due to a back problem was a setback, but he is expected to return for the five ODIs starting on 15 March.

The passage discusses the ongoing legal issues surrounding the transfer of Neymar from Santos to Barcelona. Despite Barcelona's insistence that they had not committed any offense, a judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. The club has now made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to cover potential interpretations of the contracts and to defend its reputation. The total cost of Neymar, including the initial fee, signing-on fee, wages, agents' fees, and the latest tax payment, is £106.8m. Neymar has performed well for Barcelona, scoring seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. The Metropolitan Police flew to Thailand to assist the Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21. The suspects allegedly confessed to the murders but have not withdrawn their confessions. They are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery and could face the death penalty if found guilty. The UK police are returning to the UK to compile a report and update the families of the victims. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding DNA sample verification and allegations of mistreatment.

The Scots women's soccer team has won all five qualifiers to date and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, aiming to secure their place in the major competition. Coach Evans is determined to avoid the heartbreak of previous play-off losses. Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland, is also unbeaten after four wins. The outcome of the match and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September will likely decide who tops the group. Scotland is in pole position to reach the finals in the Netherlands without a play-off, while Iceland is the top seeds. The team includes players from various leagues, such as Bayern Munich, English clubs, and the United States National Women's Soccer League.

The passage discusses the implementation of two-step verification (2SV) by Apple to enhance the security of its iCloud service, following a series of high-profile hacks where intimate photos of celebrities were stolen and posted online. The 2SV system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app after entering their username and password on a new device. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud is denied, and users are blocked from making purchases through iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store. Users can also use a 14-character recovery key to regain access if their trusted device is lost or stolen, but this key must be kept in a safe place.

Apple had previously offered the 2SV system but only activated it when users manually switched it on. The recent changes make the 2SV the default option, addressing a vulnerability where hackers could still access iCloud data using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, a tool that bypasses password protection on Apple devices. The owner of Elcomsoft, Vladimir Katalov, acknowledged that his software was likely used in the recent hacks and that Apple's new security measures effectively counteract this technique.

Katalov, however, expressed concerns about the recovery key, noting its complexity and the risk of it being lost or stolen. Another security expert, Prof Alan Woodward, from the University of Surrey, suggested that Apple should make 2SV the default setting and encourage users to use stronger passwords. Apple has indicated plans to more aggressively promote the use of 2SV and stronger passwords, with CEO Tim Cook emphasizing the need for increased user awareness and education.

The passage provides a summary of the campaign expenditures of various political parties during the European election campaign. UKIP, which won the election, spent £2,956,737, closely followed by the Tories with £2,980,815. The Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs, while Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339. The campaign period covered from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP's spending was 68p per vote, Labour 26p, the Conservatives 79p, and the Lib Dems 1.45 per vote. The Green Party, which came fourth, spent £534,249, or 43p per vote. The six highest-spending parties, including the SNP, spent a total of £9,347,087. Notably, all parties except Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

The passage discusses two recent football transfers involving Barrow's National League rivals. Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left his contract with Barrow by mutual consent to join their rivals. He has previously played for Aldershot and Exeter, and has also had a stint in Italy. There is a possibility that Anderson could face his former club on 18 February. 

On the other hand, Keating, a 21-year-old striker, has been recommended to Barrow's manager Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams, the former manager of Port Vale. Keating has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, and his move to Barrow is subject to international clearance. Nicholson praised Anderson as a leader and a player with the stature and voice he has been looking for, while describing Keating as young, raw, but incredibly hungry to prove himself. Barrow is currently four points above the relegation zone and has only won one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." The incident, though rare, is not linked to any significant underlying health issues. The horse, Many Clouds, had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime."

The passage describes a poignant farewell session in the Scottish Parliament, where several prominent figures, including Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, and former First Minister Alex Salmond, are stepping down as MSPs ahead of the election on 5 May. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, used his valedictory address to reiterate his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse," emphasizing the need for the parliament to take greater responsibility in governance. He welcomed the Scotland Bill's transfer of powers to Holyrood but noted that it did not fully meet the pledges made during the independence referendum campaign. Salmond also joked about the competition he faced from the Cheltenham races and wished all candidates good luck. Marwick thanked Salmond for his contributions and praised his service. McNeil, in his speech, highlighted the need for Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also bid farewell, joking about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage details the casting and release information for a live-action adaptation of the 1991 animated film "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens playing the Beast and Luke Evans as the villainous Gaston. Josh Gad will voice Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, the father of Belle, and Emma Thompson will voice Mrs. Potts, the housekeeper magically transformed into a teapot. The film, directed by Bill Condon, is scheduled for release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017 and begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions regarding charges in the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. Ninety-six football fans were killed in the disaster, and new inquests last year concluded that the fans were unlawfully killed. In January, files of evidence relating to 23 suspects were referred to the CPS. The CPS will inform the families of the decisions at a private meeting in Warrington.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, with a former inmate noting the prison is "notorious" for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the hard work of staff but recognizes the need for more effective measures to combat contraband. A local resident reported witnessing packages being thrown over the wall four times in two weeks, and the prison has requested community input on response strategies. The Ministry of Justice has introduced laws allowing for prisoners to be jailed for up to two years for smuggling packages over prison walls, though they deny evidence of drones being used to deliver contraband.

The passage describes a court case where Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, was accused of causing serious injury to Sylvia Blackburn, 72, outside Bedford Road Lower School. Wright claimed he was blinded by the setting sun and failed to stop at a red light, hitting Mrs. Blackburn as she was escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road. Mrs. Blackburn, a 20-year veteran lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries and is now being treated in residential care. Wright expressed remorse for his actions and the impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses the athletic career of Hannah Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner from Scotland. Muir has been unable to participate in the Commonwealth Games in April 2018 due to her veterinary medicine studies, which will keep her busy until May. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m events at the World Athletics Championships. Despite her disappointment, Muir is confident about her future, mentioning that she has at least two, and possibly three more Olympics in her. She is also considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target.

The passage describes the ongoing search for Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man who disappeared in December 2000 after walking home from a Christmas party. A search of a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, began on Saturday morning, involving excavations expected to take several weeks. Earlier this year, a team of six detectives reviewed Deely's disappearance, enhancing CCTV footage from the night he went missing to show him talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street. The man was later seen following Deely on Haddington Road. Gardaí have not yet identified the man and are renewing their appeal for him to come forward.

In the passage, Del Potro, an Argentine tennis player, secured a 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 victory over the Swiss player Stan Wawrinka. Del Potro, who is currently ranked 165th in the world, has been out of action for more than two years due to injury problems. He is in the same half of the draw as Britain's Andy Murray and will next play either France's 32nd seed Lucas Pouille or American Donald Young. The former US Open champion, 27, reached the Wimbledon semi-finals in 2013 but is playing in his first Grand Slam since the Australian Open in 2014 after having three wrist operations. Del Potro struggled early on but fought back to win the match. The crowd was supportive, and he expressed his happiness and excitement at being back on the court.

The passage discusses the resolution of two significant issues for Tunisia and Morocco in relation to the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia faced expulsion from the tournament after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial penalty call in their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea in 2015. However, an apology to Caf resolved the issue, and Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was secured. Morocco, which was initially banned from the 2017 qualifying draw, was able to enter after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned the ban. The Moroccan FA chief, Fouzi Lekjaa, expressed optimism about the future of African football, emphasizing that the impact of the ban was minimal. The passage also provides details about the 2017 Nations Cup group stages, with Tunisia facing Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, and Morocco facing Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

The passage discusses the history and current state of the McLaren Formula 1 team. Despite having won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, McLaren has experienced a significant decline in recent years. The team's struggles began in 2013 when they lost their way in chassis design, despite still having the best engine. The Honda power-unit has since become a problem for the team. 

McLaren's history is marked by cycles of triumph and decline. They achieved their greatest successes with Honda, winning 15 out of 16 races in 1988 with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. They dominated the next four years but then spent several years in the doldrums before more resounding success with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines in 1998-99. 

The team's last constructors' title was in 1999 with Hakkinen. They came close to winning again in 2007 but were disqualified from the constructors' championship and fined $100m after being found guilty of benefiting from illegal Ferrari technical information. Another scandal, known as "lie-gate," occurred in 2009 when Lewis Hamilton and sporting director Dave Ryan misled the stewards at the Australian Grand Prix. 

Ron Dennis, who took control of the team in 1984 and stepped back in 2009, returned after the team's disastrous 2013 season. Dennis believes that McLaren will break Mercedes' hegemony in F1 and become the next team to win the title. He is confident that the car is among the best this year and that next year's Honda engine will be even better. However, the team currently has no wins and is struggling to regain their past glory.

The passage describes a legal case in Dungiven, where paramedics were called to Joe's Bar at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 due to a sudden death. The court heard that alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST, leading the judge to order the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both from the same address, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge criticized O'Neill, the license holder, for her "appalling record" and expressed concern over his lack of power to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season by scoring 45 points and hitting eight three-pointers, leading the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry entered the game four shy of his mark of 272 three-pointers, which he set two years ago. He teamed with Klay Thompson to bring the Warriors back from a 13-point deficit. The Warriors avoided their first three-game losing streak this season. Lamarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds for the Blazers, who have already locked up the Northwest division.

The passage describes an unexpected encounter at Liverpool's training ground, Melwood, where YouTube star Bas van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, met with Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic. Initially, the players believed van Velzen was a fan who had won the opportunity to receive a dead-ball masterclass. However, as the session progressed, it became clear that van Velzen was a skilled free-kick taker, impressing the Liverpool players with his abilities. Van Velzen, who has gained fame on YouTube for his free-kick videos, enjoyed the experience of meeting his football idols and playing with them, even if he pretended to be a poor free-kick taker. He also surprised Balotelli by showing him his famous slogan t-shirt, which Balotelli wore during Manchester City's 6-1 win over United in October 2011.

The passage discusses a study that found women diagnosed with breast cancer who carry the BRCA1 gene can significantly reduce their risk of death by having their ovaries removed. The study, conducted by researchers in Canada, analyzed 676 breast cancer patients who had one of the mutated genes, with nearly half (345) undergoing an oophorectomy after their diagnosis. The study found that the 20-year survival rate for the entire group was 77.4%, and having an oophorectomy was associated with a 62% reduction in breast cancer death in women with a BRCA1 mutation. For BRCA1 carriers who had their ovaries removed within two years of diagnosis, there was a 73% reduction in death compared to those who did not undergo the procedure. The protective effect of oophorectomy against breast cancer was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The study suggests that oophorectomy should become part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancers.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The train, the Carolinian (train no. 80), was heading from Charlotte to New York City when the accident occurred. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The couple was pronounced dead at the scene. The train resumed its route after a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes. A man who met the couple while collecting scrap metal suggested they may have lived in a homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for a promise of U.S. citizenship. After retiring due to declining health, Toro is now facing deportation to Colombia, where he fears for his life. Despite his significant contributions to the DEA, including helping to bring down Carlos Lehder Rivas and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, Toro has not received his promised citizenship. The DEA has refused to assist him with his citizenship application after he went public with his situation. Toro is currently living in the U.S. illegally and is in limbo, trying to obtain a green card or passport to avoid deportation.

The passage discusses the actions of a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., which has been using the new top-level domain name ".sucks" to extract significant sums of money from celebrities and companies, including Kevin Spacey, YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, Yahoo, and Telus Mobility. The company has sold these domain names to trademark holders and celebrities for around $2,000 to $2,499 annually, with the intention of creating platforms for companies to interact with their critics. However, this practice has been criticized as a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory" by the intellectual property constituency and other industry groups. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) has sent a letter to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to investigate the legality of Vox Populi's actions. If found illegal, ICANN could declare the company in breach of its contract and seek to change its behavior. Vox Populi has also faced backlash for recommending a $2,499 annual fee for the ".sucks" domain and for planning to offer consumers the right to secure a ".sucks" address for just $10 a year starting in September.

A baby boy's body was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating on a village pond in 1988. The case remained unsolved for 27 years until a periodical review led to the exhumation of the boy's body from his grave in Norfolk. A DNA sample from the boy's leg bone was compared to the national police database, leading to the identification of his mother. The woman, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped after she explained that the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy from her family and friends. She admitted to placing the dead baby in the pond, known as Windmill Pit, in the village of Weasenham St Peter on June 5, 1988. The boy was originally buried without a name, but a support group for parents of stillborn children raised money for a new headstone giving his name as Peter after the name of the church. A second post-mortem carried out on the remains last year found no evidence of foul play, and an inquest held in 1988 also failed to establish a cause of death. The baby boy was re-buried in the churchyard on June 5 last year, the 26th anniversary of his discovery. The police are now satisfied that nobody else was involved in the incident.

The core pieces of information in the passage are as follows:

1. A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of a moving taxi.
2. The incident occurred in 2010 in Bath, Somerset, when Kristopher Hicks, then 23, was on his way home from a night out with his girlfriend in a taxi driven by Michael Young, a former soldier.
3. Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson.
4. When Hicks objected, Young continued driving for almost a mile, leading Hicks to jump from the vehicle while it was traveling at more than 20 mph.
5. Hicks suffered devastating brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires round-the-clock care from his mother.
6. Hicks' family took Young to the High Court, where a judge ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned his passenger.
7. The judge ruled that Hicks was entitled to damages, but the exact amount is yet to be decided and is expected to be around 50% of what the family had requested, estimated to be "hundreds of thousands of pounds."
8. The judge also awarded Hicks an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment.
9. Lawyers representing Hicks stated that the incident left him with "devastating" brain injuries and that he is now being cared for by his mother, Gill, and is unable to work.
10. Both sides were given permission to appeal, and a further hearing will determine the exact amount of compensation Young will have to pay.

The passage describes a severe weather event that occurred on Wednesday night, with tornado sirens blaring in Kansas as several storms brought reports of twisters. A tornado was reported about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, which moved to the northeast, missing the city but posing potential risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. Other tornado reports came in from southwestern Kansas, with three sightings near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. Kansas was not the only state affected; a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, causing wind damage and flooding. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

The passage discusses the upcoming middleweight clash between Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida in New Jersey on Saturday. Rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive victory since his loss to Vitor Belfort two years ago and is eyeing a title shot. He is confident in his ability to beat Machida by being the "bull" and dominating him, cutting him off, and putting him in a bad spot. Rockhold believes he has a broader avenue to win the fight compared to Machida, who has a smaller chance on the feet and less ground game. Despite mutual respect between the two fighters, Rockhold is determined to showcase his style and dominate the fight. Machida, coming off a victory, is also confident in his ability to upset Rockhold and earn a title shot.

A light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, made an emergency take-off after landing without deploying its landing gear at the Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, initially approached the runway normally but realized his mistake when the plane touched down on its belly. The plane's propellers ricocheted off the ground, causing significant damage. Georgaklis re-engaged the engines and took off, managing to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and land safely. The incident is being investigated by the FAA. The most common causes of a gear-up landing are human error or mechanical fault.

Manuel Pellegrini, the manager of Manchester City, has admitted to being disappointed with Yaya Toure's performances this season but has vowed to support the Ivorian midfielder until the end of the season. Despite Toure's underperformance and criticism, Pellegrini dismissed calls for him to take a break. Manchester City is considering selling Toure in the summer to overhaul their aging squad, but Toure is determined to stay with the club. The team is currently struggling, having taken only 18 points from their last 39 available points, and they face West Ham without their captain, Vincent Kompany, who is injured. Goalkeeper Joe Hart has acknowledged that the players have let the manager down and that they feel they have the quality to beat anyone, but that hasn't been the case. Pellegrini has stated that while the players have responsibility, he is the one who chooses the players. Additionally, Sam Allardyce, the manager of West Ham, has warned Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players by moving to Manchester City, as he believes Cresswell is an attractive prospect for clubs looking to fill homegrown player quotas.

The passage describes the case of Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," who was set to be extradited to Italy but was allowed to remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was convicted in absentia by an Italian court in 1999 for his role as a "man of honour" in the Cosa Nostra, a Sicilian Mafia organization. He was sentenced to seven years in prison for his involvement in the Mafia, including taking bribes from builders in Palermo.

In February 2014, Rancadore lost his year-and-a-half battle against extradition and was ordered to return to Italy to serve his sentence. However, it was revealed that his case expired last October, and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn. Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. Rancadore's solicitor, Karen Todner, confirmed that the Italian Court of Appeal agreed to extinguish the conviction on the basis that it is too old to sustain a prison sentence. She is confident that the Italian government will withdraw their application for a European arrest warrant, allowing Rancadore to be discharged from the proceedings.

Rancadore was first arrested on a European arrest warrant at his semi-detached London home in August 2013. Although he was never convicted of murder, the Italian authorities wanted him to be returned to the country after he fled in 1995. During the protracted extradition proceedings at Westminster Magistrates' Court, District Judge Howard Riddle initially decided to extradite Rancadore, but later reversed his decision due to concerns about Italian prison conditions and Rancadore's serious heart condition. The Italian authorities no longer seek Rancadore's extradition, and the case will still have to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court.

The passage also touches on the broader implications of Rancadore's case, including the costs of the extradition process and the impact on the local community. Legal experts have criticized the amount of time and money spent on Rancadore's case, with one expert suggesting that the Italian authorities should have communicated the issue of the expired sentence earlier. Despite the controversy, Rancadore's neighbors expressed relief that he will not be extradited, describing him as a quiet and normal family man.

The passage discusses the upcoming Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, where Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy, is one of the three 7-2 co-favorites among the seven-runner lineup. Mr. Mole is bracketed with Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's sprinter Sacre, which will be ridden by Nico de Boinville in the absence of injured Barry Geraghty. This will be AP McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, and his final day as a professional jockey. The book of rides for his final day will not be finalized until Friday morning. Notably, it was after riding Mr. Mole to victory at Newbury in February that McCoy shocked the racing world by announcing his intention to quit riding. Other runners in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.

The passage describes the story of Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was murdered in 1975. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett, and her body was found 33 days after her disappearance. Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and crime scene photos, but she recently decided to view them. The photos showed Marcia's body in a state of severe trauma, with her mouth black, face swollen, and vomit across her body. Ritter expressed a strong desire for revenge upon seeing the photos. Barrett, who was 68 at the time of the passage, was found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The case was notorious for 33 years before Barrett's conviction.

The passage discusses Rory McIlroy's belief that it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete his career grand slam. McIlroy, the world number one, has revealed that his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 was the most important day of his career. He is looking to claim his first green jacket and become the sixth player to win all four major titles, following in the footsteps of Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. McIlroy has just one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, but he is determined to complete his grand slam of majors with a victory at Augusta later this month. He believes that winning the Masters would be a significant achievement, as it would be a testament to his ability to win every major, which are played on different courses and under different conditions. McIlroy has faced significant personal challenges, including the cancellation of his wedding to Caroline Wozniacki and a legal dispute with his former management company, but he has used the golf course as a "sanctuary" to escape the pressure and focus on his game.

The passage highlights several trending stories from the previous week. In New York, a rare phenomenon occurred when four rainbows appeared in the sky after heavy rainfall, captured by Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company. In rural China, hiring exotic dancers for wakes has become a common practice, but this is now under scrutiny due to the country's crackdown on vice. Ryan Reynolds, known as RDJ, became increasingly agitated during a Channel 4 interview in the UK when asked about his private life. The passage also mentions the "Kylie Jenner Challenge," a trend where people suck on a jar to plump their lips, inspired by Kylie Jenner. A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, was featured for her prom-posal that referenced historical events, though it faced controversy. Ewan McGregor's casting as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast" and Johnny Depp's transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer also gained attention. The passage concludes with a humorous note about a military father who photobombed his son's photo, showcasing originality.

The passage highlights the alarming issue of children being born with brain damage due to exposure to alcohol in the womb, with 272 youngsters left disabled by Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) being hospitalized in England over the past year. The actual number of children affected by their mother's drinking could be much higher, as experts warn. According to research by the World Health Organization, at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure, equating to about 7,500 children annually. The passage also provides a personal account of Niamh Brown, a 15-year-old with FAS, who requires constant care and will never be able to live independently. Other medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. The government advises pregnant women not to drink alcohol, with a maximum of two units no more than twice a week, but some experts believe this guidance should be stricter, advising women not to drink at all during pregnancy.

The passage describes the arrest and sentencing of Shaun Andrew McKerry, a notorious ex-juvenile offender known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" due to his habit of returning home after committing crimes. On March 15, 2015, at 8 PM, McKerry, 31, attempted to rob the Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham. He burst in, masked and wielding an axe, demanding cash from the terrified assistant, Andrea Brighty. However, the robbery was thwarted when the store owner, Sab Dhillon, tackled McKerry to the floor, causing shelves and produce to tumble. Sab's wife, Sam, then intervened by hitting McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him. The police arrived shortly after, and McKerry was arrested. He pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court and was sentenced to six years in prison. McKerry's criminal history includes 80 arrests by the age of 15, convictions for various offenses, and a reputation for returning home after committing crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors, Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley, have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fuelled party at a Canadian barracks. They must stay in Nova Scotia until their trial and have been given identical bail conditions, including living at the nearby Stadacona naval base in Halifax, surrendering their passports, and drawing their current pay from the Royal Navy. The alleged sexual assault took place on April 10 after the sailors returned to the barracks from a hockey game. The four men appeared in court in Dartmouth, near Halifax, and were ordered to return on May 27. They are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which are punishable by up to 14 years in prison.

The passage describes the harrowing experience of Valerie Jackson, the mother of a four-year-old boy named RJ Jackson, who suffers from Netherton's syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease. RJ's skin appears red and scaly, and he is one of only 70 people in the world with this condition. Valerie's life has been marked by the challenges of caring for her son, who requires frequent application of creams to prevent his skin from drying out and to alleviate his pain. Despite these efforts, Valerie and RJ have faced significant social and legal challenges, including being reported to the police for child abuse by a stranger who mistook the symptoms of Netherton's syndrome for signs of abuse. Valerie has also encountered taunts and bullying from other people, who often misunderstand the nature of her son's condition. The passage highlights the rarity and misunderstanding of Netherton's syndrome, emphasizing the need for greater public awareness and education.

The passage describes the controversy surrounding a series of advertisements by the online fitness store Protein World, which feature a bikini-clad model named Renee Somerfield and the slogan "Are you beach body ready?" The advertisements, which ran around the London Underground, have sparked significant backlash from feminists and body image campaigners. A Change.org petition calling for the removal of the posters has garnered over 50,000 signatures, and several images have been defaced by bloggers who are angry at the perceived implication that only women who look like Renee are ready to go to the beach. The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) has received over 200 complaints about the adverts, with many arguing that they promote an unhealthy body image. 

Transport for London (TFL) has confirmed that the posters are being removed because they have reached the end of their three-week advertising period. The company has also noted the strong reaction from customers and indicated that they will consider this feedback if they receive a request to place similar advertisements in the future. The removal of the posters comes as a protest against Protein World in Hyde Park on May 2 is gaining momentum, with hundreds of people expected to attend the rally in central London. The posters have also caused a significant backlash on social media, with many users expressing their disapproval and describing the campaign as "anxiety-inducing" and "sexist." 

Protein World, which claims the image is entirely unphotoshopped, has defended its campaign, arguing that it is targeted at health-conscious individuals looking to get fit for the summer. The company's head of global marketing, Richard Staveley, has defended the advertising, saying it is meant to inspire people to be healthier and more confident. However, the company has also received threats and a bomb threat, which have been reported to the police. Despite the controversy, Staveley has declared the campaign a "fantastic" success and stated that the company will not change its advertising methods in the future.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding a series of fare hikes proposed by rail firms, particularly First Great Western (FGW), just ten days after the general election. Despite the main party leaders' pledges to freeze prices, FGW plans to increase fares by up to 87% on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which passes through Prime Minister David Cameron's Witney constituency. In response, Cameron has requested that FGW "urgently review" its decision, promising to freeze fares in real terms for the entire next parliament. Labour has also pledged to introduce a "cap" on price hikes.

The specific fare increase in question affects passengers traveling from Charlbury, the Oxfordshire station nearest to Cameron's constituency home. Currently, an off-peak return to London costs £33.30, but from May 17, this will rise to £62.40, representing an 87% increase. This has angered Cameron's constituents, leading him to personally intervene. The prime minister's spokesman confirmed that Cameron has written to FGW to request an urgent review of the fare increase.

Train companies have three windows each year to increase "unregulated" fares, which account for about half of their total revenue. Unregulated fares include off-peak leisure and advance-purchase tickets. FGW claims the fare increase is necessary to align the North Cotswolds route with its other services. The company is also offering a cheaper advanced single ticket option, potentially allowing customers to purchase a return for £20 if they book in advance.

Other significant price hikes include an off-peak first-class single from Crewe to Northampton on London Midlands, which will rise from £30 to £37, and an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool with Virgin, which will increase from £26.50 to £33, a 24.5% hike. The biggest increase is for passengers traveling between London and the Cotswolds, with fares potentially rising by up to 87%.

Virgin has defended its price hikes, stating that the "vast majority" of its increases affect "Virgin Trains-only fares," which are at least 20% cheaper than tickets offered by rival firms. Virgin also noted that its overall fare increase on the West Coast this year is just 1.65%, well below the industry average. Mike Richardson of Trainsplit.com noted that passengers might be surprised by these fare increases, given the main parties' promises to freeze prices. He also mentioned that hundreds of "anytime" and "off-peak" returns rose by 40% in January, and his research found significant fare increases on tickets bought on the day and on rural routes.

The passage describes a violent attack on former soldier John Young, 66, and his new wife Elaine, 54, in their home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The couple, who had just married 14 months ago, were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts when they were attacked. Thugs began pelting the front window of their home with stones, and when John Young opened the door to confront the attackers, he was struck in the face with a brick, causing an open wound to his forehead and a serious injury to his left eye. Despite emergency surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight, leaving him blind in one eye. The attack occurred just three weeks after their marriage and has left the couple feeling unsafe in their own home. Police are investigating the incident but have noted the lack of a clear motive, suggesting it may have been a case of youths "messing around." The couple plans to move to a new flat in Southport due to their fear of returning to the neighborhood.

Tom Poynton, a wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a new one-year contract extension after successfully returning from injury. Poynton, 25, missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident in which his father Keith died. He underwent an ankle operation and made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's character and hard work, and expressed hope that the new contract will give him the confidence to perform well during the upcoming season.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with an aggressive form of neuroblastoma, a rare and serious childhood cancer, has been given the all clear by doctors after a year of intense treatment. Harley, from Stretford, decorated his protective mask with a ninja turtle design to help him feel stronger during his radiotherapy sessions. The hospital staff were amazed by his bravery and creativity. After his story gained international attention, staff at the children's TV channel Nickelodeon sent him a box full of ninja turtle presents for Christmas. Harley's parents, Oliver and Stacey, were overjoyed to receive the news that he is cancer-free. He will undergo regular check-ups to ensure he stays free of the disease. Neuroblastoma is a cancer of specialized nerve cells and affects fewer than 100 children in the UK each year. Most children diagnosed with the disease are younger than five years old, and it is the second most common solid tumour in childhood. The cancer can spread to various parts of the body, including bone marrow, bone, lymph nodes, liver, and skin. Harley's bravery caught the attention of doctors, and he was awarded one of Cancer Research UK's Little Star Awards. He has also become the face of the charity's Kids and Teens campaign, which aims to raise funds for research into child cancers.

The passage discusses Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, who has impressed in his team's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. Grealish is currently at the center of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England, both of which are interested in him for their national teams. Tim Sherwood, a teammate and former professional, advises Grealish to focus on his club career with Aston Villa before making a decision about his international future. Sherwood highlights Grealish's confidence and skill, noting that he is not overawed by playing with the first team and that his performances will determine his international choices. Grealish's father, Kevin, also supports the idea of concentrating on club football first. The passage concludes by mentioning that Grealish is expected to make a decision between Ireland and England at the end of the season.

The passage discusses the significant differences in landing fees at various airports, which disproportionately affect private jet travelers. Private jet travel is a luxury accessible only to the wealthy, and the costs associated with landing fees can be substantial, often reaching thousands of dollars per flight. The passage highlights several unexpectedly popular transport hubs for the rich and famous, such as Salzburg in Austria and Darwin in Australia, which charge high landing fees.

The private jet industry is growing, with 2.5 million private flights recorded in the US in 2013 and 705,000 in Europe. The market value of this industry is substantial, estimated at $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe. The busiest weekends for private jet travel coincide with major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl in the US and the Monaco Grand Prix.

The passage provides a list of the most expensive airports for landing fees, based on the cost for a 767-400 aircraft, which can hold up to 50 passengers. The top three most expensive airports are all in Japan: Haneda Airport in Tokyo ($6,850), Narita International Airport in Tokyo ($5,600), and Kansai International Airport in Osaka ($5,400). Other notable airports include Dublin Airport in Ireland ($4,100), Bristol Airport in the UK ($4,400), and La Guardia Airport in New York ($3,950). The passage concludes by noting that the UK's Bristol Airport is the only British airport in the top 10, and the only US airport to make the list is La Guardia Airport.

The passage describes a video that has gone viral, showing a Labrador named Cooper eating ice cream at a McDonald's drive-thru. Cooper's owner, Katie Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, takes Cooper and his friend Daisy, a smaller pup, to McDonald's for ice cream. Cooper, known for his quick eating habits, finishes the ice cream cone in one bite, while Daisy takes a few ladylike licks. The video has been watched over seven million times. Gallegos defends her decision to feed the dogs ice cream, stating that Cooper is in excellent health and that he is an athlete. She also mentions that Daisy, due to her size, only gets a few licks. The passage also notes that another video shows the dogs visiting a Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," where Cooper again takes the whole cup in his mouth to finish the contents.

Gary Locke, the interim manager of Kilmarnock, has been appointed as the club's permanent manager after signing a three-year contract. He took over the team in February when his former teammate, Allan Johnston, resigned. Since then, Locke has led the team to seven games without losing any, and he will address the media at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, for using essential oils manufactured by Doterra. The oils, which include scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, are applied to Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Teachers at Seminole County Elementary warned they would remove Logan from class due to the oils' scent being a distraction to other students. Despite the threat of punishment, Kemp plans to continue using the oils and has received support from the Lake County School District, which stated that the issue is a "health issue" and will not suspend Logan.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, known as the Sandpiper, was completely destroyed by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The blaze spread through 90 condos, and despite the efforts of 12 fire crews, the fire was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings. The fire was so severe that it could be seen from three miles away. The complex, which is used as a holiday home by residents from May to November, was completely obliterated, with the building manager, Rob Taber, losing everything. Firefighters used cranes to approach the fire due to its intensity, which prevented them from entering the building. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with initial reports suggesting it may have started near a car parked by the complex.

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II's love for horses and her continued enjoyment of riding, despite her advanced age. At 88 years old, the Queen was spotted riding in Windsor Great Park on her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, accompanied by a groom on another of her ponies. She is known for her reluctance to wear a riding helmet, preferring instead to use a silk scarf, a habit she has maintained since her early days of riding. The Queen's passion for horses began at the age of four when she was given a Shetland pony named Peggy. Over the years, she has owned various horses, including Betsy, her favorite mount in the 1950s, and Surprise, the horse she rode at Ascot in 1961. Despite a recent knee injury that has reduced her riding, the Queen remains an enthusiastic equestrienne and continues to breed several breeds of horses and ponies, including Fell ponies and Highland ponies. The Fell pony, like the one she rides, has a long history dating back to the Neolithic period and has been prized by various cultures, including the Romans and Vikings. Today, the Fell pony remains a popular choice for riders of all ages, and the Queen continues to breed them at her Hampton Court stud.

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbours over noise levels escalated into a tragic incident, resulting in the death of one man and the other being charged with manslaughter. Leon Yeaman, 55, was allegedly killed by a single punch from his neighbour, 28-year-old Philip Pama, who was a married father of three. Pama, who works a 3 AM shift at a nearby warehouse, was reportedly sleeping when Yeaman was making noise. Pama's defence lawyer, Bruce Peters, stated that Yeaman was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling at the world. The argument between the two men escalated, and Pama allegedly grabbed Yeaman by the hand and hit out blindly, resulting in Yeaman's death. Pama was granted conditional bail and ordered to surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew, and report to the local police station twice a week. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

The passage describes a case involving a 52-year-old Russian music teacher, Yulia Simonova, who, after being jilted by a 15-year-old pupil, Damian Vanya, sought to hire a hitman to torture and murder him. Simonova had showered Vanya with gifts and money for a year before he ended their relationship for a classmate. She asked a friend to find someone willing to torture and kill Vanya in exchange for 100,000 rubles (£1,400). 

Police set up a sting operation, sending an undercover officer to pose as a hitman during a meeting with Simonova in the Russian city of Shatura, near Moscow. A hidden camera recorded the exchange, where Simonova, still emotionally invested in the relationship, ordered the hitman to break Vanya's arms and legs, damage his kidneys, and make him bleed to death before she would join in to "finish him." 

After Simonova handed over part of the £1,400, she was arrested by armed police in her car. She was searched and taken to a police station, where she was remanded in custody on charges of attempted murder. Vanya, who had broken off the relationship with Simonova for a classmate, expressed relief and wished for her to face severe consequences, saying he hoped the guards would "throw away the key" for her prison cell.

The passage discusses Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho's personal life and beliefs. Mourinho, a father of two, talks to God every day but never about football. He believes in God strongly and prays daily, though he does not attend church every day or even every week. He only prays for personal matters and not for Chelsea. Mourinho tries to separate his professional and family life, stating that he is a good person and a good family man. Despite his intensely competitive persona on the sideline, he claims to be a good friend and tries to support people he doesn't even know. Mourinho acknowledges that he makes mistakes in his professional life, which is competitive and emotional, but emphasizes that a person is more than just their professional life.

The passage describes Bob Barker, a TV game show legend, returning to host "The Price is Right" for the first time in eight years. Barker, who hosted the show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, was welcomed back by contestants with the classic phrase "come on down!" He handled the first price-guessing game of the show, "Lucky Seven," and then handed over the hosting duties to Drew Carey, who finished the episode. Despite being away from the show for most of the past eight years, Barker appeared spry at 91 and seamlessly resumed his role as host.

The passage details the arrest of off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin in Washington D.C. on Friday morning, where he was accused of attempting to break into a house at midnight. Baldwin was taken into custody by the Metropolitan Police at 12:30 am on the 3200 block of D Street SE. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. In response to the arrest, the Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin is part of the foreign missions branch of the Secret Service, which is attached to the State Department and deals with U.S. diplomatic activities. Court records show Baldwin was scheduled for arraignment on Friday afternoon, but his attorney and phone number were not listed. Baldwin's arrest comes amidst a series of controversies within the Secret Service, including the recent leave of a high-ranking supervisor accused of misconduct, which is also under investigation by the Homeland Security Department's inspector general. Additionally, the inspector general is investigating a March 4 incident where two high-ranking agency officials are accused of driving into a secure area at the White House after a night of drinking.

The passage describes a daring encounter between a freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, and a hungry lion. Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, ventured into the city's safari park to capture an image of a male lion. He exited his car and crept up to the lion, lying on the ground just 10 feet away, using only his camera. Despite the risk, he managed to take a couple of frames before the lion, alerted by the camera's shutter sound, charged towards him. Saeed quickly scrambled back into his car, narrowly escaping the lion's attack. He reflects on the experience, acknowledging the close call and the thrill of the moment, but also expressing doubt about attempting such a risky photography stunt again.

The New York City Police Department (NYPD) has released an image of a tattoo found on the body of an unidentified woman in Brooklyn, hoping to identify her nearly a month after her death. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. Paramedics were unable to revive her, and she was pronounced dead that evening. The distinctive tattoo, found on her right leg, is a faded heart with a rose on top and the name "Monique" etched across a tattooed ribbon. Despite the lack of identification, the NYPD is still awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of her death. Anyone with information about the woman is urged to contact the NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-tips.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 hino flatbed truck. They purchased the truck in 2009 after returning from living in the UK and started the project, which took about a year and a half to complete. The home, now located in Nelson, New Zealand, is nearly self-sufficient, powered by solar panels, with gas-powered heating and hot water, and water sourced from a nearby spring. The couple, who spent around $25,000 on the project, plan to build another similar home in the future.

The passage discusses a study by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, which found that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who do not use the devices or use them individually. The study involved 352 kindergarten students over an academic year. Shared iPad students scored around 30 points higher than those who used the device on their own and non-iPad users. Blackwell emphasizes that the collaborative learning around the technology, rather than the collaboration itself, is what makes the difference. She suggests that schools should reconsider how tablets are used, especially in early grades, to maximize the technology's effectiveness. The findings will be presented at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

A little piggy, born without hind legs, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters. The heartwarming video shows the piglet taking unsteady steps and wobbling about, but it always manages to regain its balance. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," happily mixes with its siblings, who have all four legs. The piglet belongs to a farmer in Sichuan province, China, and has captured the hearts of thousands since the video went online.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured during the inaugural Indycar Grand Prix of Louisiana when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car on Sunday. Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was hit while Dracone was in the pits for tires and fuel on lap 25. Dracone spun out of the pit box, causing Phillips to be clipped by the car. Phillips was taken to the infield care center for treatment, where he received stitches for a cut on his leg and was subsequently released. The race faced challenges with traction due to rainfall before the event, and Dracone did not finish the race, finishing 23rd.

The passage describes a horrific incident where a husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, also known as Amanda Bueno. The crime was captured on CCTV footage, showing Severiano dragging his unconscious wife into the garden of their apartment in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. He then proceeded to slam her head into concrete paving 11 times and punch her in the face 10 times. After leaving her battered and unconscious, he returned to the house, retrieved a handgun, and shot her in the face five times at point-blank range. Severiano later confessed to the murder, stating that his actions were driven by jealousy over men looking at his wife. The couple had been married for only four days at the time of the incident. Neighbors reported hearing a terrible argument and the subsequent silence until the gunshots were heard. Severiano fled the scene in a stolen car but was apprehended after crashing it. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his vehicle. Severiano is now facing life in jail.

The passage discusses Sarah Wilson, the journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," who has opened up about her personal battle with mental illness, including anxiety and depression. Wilson, 41, revealed that her anxiety drove her to a point where she considered taking her own life, believing she had reached a stage in her life where she "couldn't see the point of continuing." She attributes her struggles to a combination of factors, including mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feeling isolated due to her lack of a husband and children. Wilson feels that she has been "essentially very alone" and describes her anxiety as bringing her to a point where she couldn't see a light at the end of the tunnel. Despite her younger years of struggle, Wilson has recently found some peace with her condition. She emphasizes the intrinsic link between depression and anxiety and suggests that acknowledging this link is crucial for better tackling the increasing rate of Australian women affected by stress and anxiety. Wilson notes that anxiety is quickly becoming the "new depression," and she encourages those in need of help to contact Beyondblue or Lifeline for support.

The passage describes a case in which Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after she used a crowbar to beat her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend, who was shooting heroin in her bathroom. Curtin was set to go to trial in Multnomah County Circuit Court but the charge was dropped on Monday because prosecutors deemed her actions "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave a resident's home. Curtin's defense attorney, Casey Kovacic, argued that the ex-girlfriend was jealous and bitter, and had been harassing and threatening Curtin. The ex-girlfriend had also stolen from Curtin and plotted to drag her boyfriend back into addiction. Curtin gave birth in January and is now living with her parents, while her boyfriend, the father of her child, has not been a part of his new child's life.

The passage describes a video of Gemma, a pit bull in California, being fed treats. Her owner tries to trick her by adding a broccoli spear to her food. Gemma reacts with disgust, chomps on the vegetable, and then spits it out on the floor. The passage suggests that this behavior might not set a good example for the two children she lives with, hoping they learn to enjoy their greens.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was supposed to lead to the bank's page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which was shut down in 2011. The pornographic site took over the address after the awards were discontinued, and the organizers allowed its registration on hsbc.com.hk to lapse. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website after realizing the mistake and issued an apology, stating that the bank is not associated with the external third-party website. The bank's website remains secure, and it continues to offer internet banking services for account balance checks, fund transfers, loan applications, and insurance.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, provided instructions during a 911 call and successfully rescued himself and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah from their burning home in Clinton. The fire broke out on the first floor, trapping them in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus called 911, stayed calm throughout the 11-minute call, and gave detailed directions to firefighters. He soothed his sister when she said they were going to die and instructed her to stay low and breathe. Prince George's County firefighters entered the room by breaking a window and rescued the siblings. Firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward handed Marcus out the window and gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

The passage describes a phenomenon where blue fluorescent algae, known as noctiluca scintillans, illuminates Australia's east coast, particularly in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured stunning images of the neon glow illuminating a popular beach, describing the scene as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. This phenomenon is similar to one observed in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Oceanography expert Iain Suthers, from the University of New South Wales, explains that the algae blooms naturally in the spring and autumn, and in 90% of cases, the glow is due to natural causes. The glowing algae, which preys on another type of algae called diatoms, uses the luminous glow as a defense mechanism.

The passage discusses a new test that can help breast cancer patients avoid chemotherapy by identifying genetic markers in the tumor that determine its aggressiveness. After surgery, cancer cells are sent to a lab for screening, and women can be informed within days whether they have a high or low risk of the disease returning. The test, called endopredict, can accurately predict a low risk of recurrence as low as five percent, which is comparable to or better than the odds for those who have chemotherapy. The majority of breast cancer patients are currently given chemotherapy after tumor removal to prevent recurrence, but this treatment is often grueling with side effects such as hair loss, nausea, and fatigue. Some women find the prospect of chemotherapy more daunting than the surgery itself. Experts believe that certain women have a lower risk of cancer recurrence and may not need chemotherapy. The endopredict test can help patients make an informed decision about whether to undergo chemotherapy. While most of these tests are currently available only privately and cost about £2,500, breast specialists hope they may soon be available on the NHS. Surgeon Hemant Singhal and Professor Kefah Mokbel, a consultant breast surgeon at St George's Hospital in London, support the use of these tests on the NHS, arguing that the cost is balanced by savings from not giving chemotherapy. Becca Cornford, a 49-year-old mother of three, was diagnosed with breast cancer and found that she had cancer in her other breast. She was initially scheduled for chemotherapy but was relieved to learn that her chances of recurrence were only five percent, and chemotherapy would not significantly improve her odds. She decided against chemotherapy, preferring regular monitoring instead.

The passage discusses the issue of pregnant women being airlifted from Royal Navy ships. Over the past nine years, more than 25 women have been airlifted from navy ships due to pregnancy, with one ship, HMS Ocean, having five pregnant sailors removed in emergency "medevacs." HMS Illustrious, nicknamed "HMS Lusty," also had at least one pregnant woman airlifted. Eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, had emergency evacuations. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting that the women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave. The data comes nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Navy sources stated that Ms. West left HMS Portland for "personal reasons," and the Ministry of Defence would not confirm the reasons or the action she would face. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, around 9% of personnel were female. Last May, three women became the first female submariners to serve in the Royal Navy. Nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after finding out they were pregnant, with 99 servicewomen evacuated from operations between January 2006 and December 2013. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones, and the women were flown back on flights reserved for injured troops. Troops are reminded to check they are not pregnant before flying to the front line, but are not made to do pregnancy tests. Most of the babies would have been conceived before the mother left the UK, but a small number of women may have become pregnant on tour.

A drone carrying traces of a radioactive material was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House, raising concerns about the potential for terrorism involving drones. The discovery came on the same day a Japanese court approved a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant in Kagoshima prefecture, more than four years after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. The drone, spotted by a staff member on Wednesday morning, had four propellers and was 50 centimeters wide. It was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. The amount of cesium inside is not immediately harmful to humans. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said the discovery is raising concerns about terrorism, particularly in relation to future events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports but does not restrict flights around the prime minister's residence or government buildings. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was not in his office at the time, as he was in Indonesia attending the Asian-African conference.

The passage describes the heartwarming story of Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province in eastern China, who takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike. Lu Xincai is concerned that his mother might get lost if left alone at home, as she often wanders off, especially after dark. After his father's passing earlier this year, he decided to bring his mother to work to ensure her safety, as his wife works in a different city and his son is still in school. Lu Xincai helps his mother get up at 5 am, places her on the motorbike, and ties a sash around both their waists to prevent her from falling off. The journey to work, which is four kilometers long, takes an hour, and Lu Xincai rides slowly to ensure his mother feels safe and they can chat. At work, he checks on her regularly, as she has been given her own room by his employers at a bank. Lu Xincai feels a deep sense of duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to caring for her children, and he expresses his relief in seeing her, fearing she might wander away if he does not.

The passage discusses a study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, which found that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012. This rise is largely attributed to increased drinking among women, who are now more likely to engage in binge drinking. The study defines heavy drinking as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once a month. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level and found that in 2012, 8 percent of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers. Despite the increases in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged over time. The study also notes that about 88,600 U.S. deaths were attributed to alcohol in 2010, and the cost of excessive drinking has been estimated at more than $220 billion per year. Public health experts offer various cultural and economic explanations for the increase in excessive drinking, including changes in social norms, the influx of wealthy professionals in cities like San Francisco and San Jose, and weakened alcohol control policies.

The World Health Organization (WHO), the UN's public health agency, warns that doctors are putting the health of women and their babies at risk by performing caesarean sections too readily. They recommend that the procedure should only be carried out when "medically necessary" due to potential infections and even death. Currently, just over a quarter of women giving birth in England have a caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The WHO suggests that the ideal rate should be between 10% and 15%. A planned caesarean costs the NHS an average of £2,369, compared to a natural birth at £1,665. The WHO's statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow for caesareans even without medical justification. The WHO also criticizes the overuse of caesareans, noting that they can lead to significant complications, disability, or death, and divert funds from other patients.

A woman, Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living inside for at least a week, and selling items from the owner's property in a yard sale. Filkins was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The homeowner, Mark Conklin, discovered her sitting in his living room and claimed ownership of the property. Filkins fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck when Conklin called the police. The police found a broken window at the front door, covered by a blanket. Filkins was arrested several hours later when she attempted to re-enter the home. She is scheduled to appear in court on May 14. A construction worker reported seeing Filkins with items from the home, and the police are asking anyone who received items to return them.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was reunited with its owner after police posted a series of humorous photos on her Facebook page to track her down. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border on Sunday morning. Police officers, realizing the phone was unlocked, used it to post selfies and photos of the phone in various locations around the police station on Bella's Facebook page. The posts included a photo of the phone in a holding "cell" and a pun about the phone being "fully charged." Bella, who lost her phone at a friend's birthday party the night before, found the police's approach amusing and appreciated their sense of humor. She eventually reclaimed her phone without having to provide her name, as the officers recognized her from her Facebook page. Bella has since added a password to her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippo was tragically killed after being caught in a fight between two adult hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf's mother, who was part of a herd, stayed with her group to avoid the danger, unaware that one of the brawling adults would grab the calf between its jaws. The calf was dragged along the water's surface and later died from its injuries. The incident was witnessed by Stacey Farrell, a tour operator, who described the mother's attempts to retrieve her baby and the calf's ultimate fate.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, has been put on the market for £575,000, significantly lower than the prices of neighboring homes. The property, located in Egerton Place, has only three years left on its lease, which would cost £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month. Despite the short lease, the apartment is described as "bright and well proportioned" with 1,990 sq/ft of space, featuring three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease to 90 years would likely cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. The property is one of two maisonettes being sold with a short lease, and both require modernization. Despite the high cost of lease extensions, the property has received significant interest from locals, developers, and end users.

Starbucks experienced a nationwide computer outage that affected 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing registers to malfunction and prompting baristas to give away free drinks. The outage began in the early evening on the East Coast and in the late afternoon on the West Coast. The company did not specify the exact cause of the outage, which was resolved late Friday night. Despite the disruption, some customers took advantage of the free drinks, and the company apologized for any inconvenience. The outage occurred just one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

The passage discusses the presence of terrorists undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. According to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, these locations are being used to radicalize Muslims. The individuals involved in such activities engage in seemingly ordinary community activities but have an ulterior motive. The passage also mentions historical incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales, tracing back to 1998 when a group of 10 extremists trained in the Brecon Beacons, an area used by the British military for training due to its rugged terrain. The passage further highlights specific cases, such as the 7/7 bombers Mohammad Sidique Khan and Shehzad Tanweer being photographed white water rafting in Bala, North Wales, and the arrest of three would-be terrorists from Cardiff in 2010 who plotted a series of terror attacks inspired by Al-Qaeda.
